An incomplete copper alloy unidentified object probably of Medieval date c.AD1200-1500. The object comprises a flat circular frame, pointed oval in section and decorated on both surfaces with a continuous row of sub-rectangular impressions forming a crenellated surface.  A flat rectangular metal strip is folded over the frame, the ends terminate in an uneven transverse break. Both sides of the strip are decorated stamped motifs forming a row of raised vertical pointed ovals flanked on each side with a raised crescent parallel to the sides of the oval. The object is worn with dark brown glossy patina remaining on some of the raised crenellations. Measurements: diameter of frame: 25.01mm: width of frame: 2.46mm; thickness of frame: 2.28mm. Width of pin: 6.21mm- 5.82mm weight: 2.93g.

A post-medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), second issue dated to 1565 on coin. Rose initial mark. Mint of London.  Ref:  North (1991: 134) no. 1997. Obverse: Crowned bust left, rose behind. Legend: ELIZABETH.D;G;AN'.FR.ET.HI: REGINA Reverse: Square shield over long cross fourchee dividing the legend. Legend: POSVI/ DEV. AD/IVTORE/M. MEV; Measurements: diameter: 25.88; thickness: 0.54mm and weight: 2.78g.

A post medieval silver threepence of Charles II (AD 1660-1685) dating c. AD 1660-1662. Mint of London. Crown initial mark. As North (1991: 210) no. 2769. Obverse: Crowned bust left with mark of value III behind head, CAROLVS II D G M BR FR ET HI REX Reverse: Square shield on cross fleury, CHRISTO AUSPICE REGNO Measurements: Diameter: 18.79mm; thickness: 0.68mm and weight: 1.44g.

A complete silver medieval penny of Edward I (AD1272-1307). Canterbury mint. Probably Class 10cf3b dating c. 1307-1309. As North (1991) no: 1042/2. Measurements: diameter: 18.13mm; thickness: 1.01mm and weight: 1.30g.

A complete post medieval gunflint and lead pad dating c. AD 1600-1900. The flint is is rectangular in plan and is of the classic wedge shape in section. The exposed section of the flint has been worked creating three visible long sloping faces and a flat upper surface on the upper dorsal side. The ventral front edge has been worked with short, scaled semi-abrupt retouch. The flint is a black to translucent brown colour. The body of the flint is wrapped in a piece of folded lead, or "flint pad", intended to hold it in place within the jaws of a cock or hammer on a flintlock firearm. There appears to be a partial impression from the lock clamp on the upper surface of the lead. Measurements: length 33.01mm, width 24.07mm, thickness 11.81mm, weight 17.46g. Discussion: Other recorded gunflints with lead pads include BERK-736C0C; KENT-CBEAF2 and NMS-A24189 which notes that the flintlock was introduced in the middle of the 16th century and became the main regulation firearm for the British Army during the reign of William III. The knapped flint was used within the musket mechanism to produce a spark and could last between 20-25 shots before it had to be replaced.

A complete silver finger ring of probable medieval date (c.1000-1200). Description: The ring is sub-circular in plan, with the back section of the hoop being rectangular in cross-section and the front sub-circular, being formed with three twisted sub-rectangular wires which have been split from the band. At some points on the wires, possible peck marks are evident which were used to test the quality of the silver.  Measurements: diameter: 24mm; width: 3.8mm; thickness: 1.2mm; height (of bezel): 3.5mm; weight: 3.91g Discussion: Typically, silver finger rings formed of twisted wire have a very narrow back such as NCL-40E866, sometimes the join of two tapering ends such as KENT-4D4DB5, both of which are attributed to Viking production and dated c.800-1100. Those with rectangular backs such as the one recorded here are less common but include SUSS-6F8D1D, dated c.800-1100, and which references multiple gold parallels including YORYM-F67716 dated 9th-11th century.  It also references an almost identical example to the ring recorded here in the British Museums collections (1854,0820.6) which was '...found in the Lark Hill Hoard near Worcester. This hoard is dated to the 12th century by the presence of coins contained therein, but the ring is described in the British Museum's collection database as being 'a common type of Viking and late Anglo-Saxon ring'. KENT-EA1868 is the closest parallel that could be found on the database and includes the following discussion: ...the twisted hoop type of Viking origin is long-lived in Denmark, in fact into the early 12th century, while in England, a ring of plain rods with a plain section hammered square at the back was found in the Lark Hill Hoard, deposited later around 1173-1174 (F. Lindahl, 2003, Symboler I guld og sølv, Nationalmuseets fingerringe 1000-1700-årene, Copenhagen, 11-13, figs. 3 and 12).  It also refers to '...a silver-gilt ring of alternating twisted rods and finer twisted wires with a long, plain, rectangular section at the back, like the one from Old Romney, from a late 13th or early 14th-century context at Hangleton, Sussex (E.W. Holden, 1963, 'Excavations at the deserted medieval village of Hangleton, part 1', Sussex Archaeological Collections, 54-181, fig. 38, 18). The form and structure of both these rings are closely comparable with a further silver stray find from either England, or possibly the Near East, in the Haedeke Collection (H.-U. Haedeke, 2000, Schmuck aus drei Jahrtausenden, Cologne, 86, cat.no. 118)'.  It concludes: 'It would appear from the occurrences in early Medieval contexts, therefore, that such rings of multiple, twisted rods with longish arcs of square section at the back of the hoop and less 'corrugated' appearance represent a development of the Viking form and can be dated to the Romanesque period.' A date of c.1000-1200 is therefore suggested for the example recorded here.

A Post-Medieval gold half-guinea of George I (1714-1727), minted in London in 1720. As Spink no: 3635. Obverse description: Bust laureate right. Obverse inscription: GEORGIVS.D’G.M.BR.FR.ET.HIB REX.FD Reverse description: Cruciform shields of Arms of England, France, Ireland and Hanover; central cross, sceptre between each pair of shields. Reverse inscription: 20.BRVN ET.L.DVX S.R.I.ATH ET.EL.17 Measurements: diameter: 20.91mm: thickness: 0.78mm; weight: 3.95g. The coin has been slightly bent twice possibly into a love token.

A copper or copper-alloy leaf shaped razor or knife dating to the Middle Bronze Age c. 2150-1500 BC. The leaf shaped blade is lenticular in cross-section. One surface is almost flat and the other slightly convex possibly with the remains of a midrib. The tang is also lenticular in cross section with opposing convex surfaces. The surface extending from the flat side of the blade steeply convex and the opposing side extending from the midrib side is gently convex and almost flat. The tang measures12.44mm at the base of the blade tapering to a point. It thickens from 7.68mm tapering to 1.75mm at the tip. The side profile of the tang terminates in a curve with a sharply upturned tip.The object is covered in pale green corrosion, but is a bright copper underneath. Measurements: length: 91.86mm; width: 32.78mm; thickness of blade: 7.31mm and weight: 51.75g. Discussion: The upturned tang would have held the original wood, bone or antler handle in place. Other similar examples on the database include: LANCUM-0FBC03; LEIC-081BB1; SF5067. See also Watson, P. 1993 no. 76, a razor metal detected in 1986 in Bewdley Worcestershire and now in Birmingham museum (1987.A218.). Elle De Spretter notes that the shape is consistent with Peggy Piggot's Class I, Butler and Smith Class Ib and Jockenhovel's double edge with long oval blade and tang. References: Butler and Smith, 1956. Razors, urns and the British Middle Bronze Age', Univ London Inst Archaeol Ann Rep Vol. 12. Piggott C.M. 1946. The Late Bronze Age Razors of the British Isles, Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society (N.S. 12 (XII)).
A fragment of a medieval silver long cross penny of uncertain ruler, class or mint.
A cut silver quarter voided long cross penny of Henry III (1216-1272). Probably class 2-3 dating to 1248-1250, London mint.
A silver halfpenny of Henry VI, first reign (1422-1461), pinecone-mascle issue. Obverse legend reads [+] hENRIC pinecone REX ◊ ANGL. London mint. As North (1991), p77, number 1468.

A lead alloy disc, probably a token, 24.1mm in diameter and of late post medieval date. One side is stamped with faint lettering which appears to be retrograde and may read WB&T / P[...]/ S(I)[...] / 17(08?). The other side is blank. The 18th century date is unclear.

A group of three uniface post medieval lead alloy tokens from the same location with cross and pellet designs. All circa 17th-18th century. From top left to bottom right in the photo (measurements are diameter, thickness, weight): 1, incomplete (20.1mm by 3.3mm, 5.97g). 2, (16.6mm by 3.9mm, 4.38g). 3, (14.0mm by 2.6mm, 1.94g).

A group of seven post medieval uniface lead alloy tokens from the same location. All circa 17th-18th century. From top left to bottom right in the photo (measurements are diameter, thickness, weight): A stylised leaf or other form with six pairs of lines or chevrons radiating from a stalk (22.5mm by 4.4mm, 13.29g). Letters IM or WI (20.8mm by 1.8mm, 5.25g). Letter T (15.9mm by 1.9mm, 2.13g). Letter T (15.5mm by 2.9mm, 4.30g). Indeterminate form, possibly a bust facing left or a keyhole shape. Reverse may have a crude letter S (18.3mm by 2.0mm, 3.52g). Letter T with three pellets (16.5mm, 2.0mm, 2.40g). A damaged token with three pellets (20.1mm by 2.9mm, 4.30g).

A uniface lead alloy token, 25.5mm in diameter. One side has a prominent coat of arms with a chevron, a small lis between two unclear elements above and another unclear element below. Possibly the arms of the worshipful company of Tylers and Bricklayers. Circa 18th century.

A copper alloy medieval single loop D-shaped buckle with a narrowed and offset strap bar and a notched pin rest flanked by small transverse ridges. Complete with a copper alloy pin curled around the bar. Circa 13th - 14th century.
A silver medieval short cross penny of John (1199-1216), class 6b2 dating from 1208-1217. Moneyer probably Robert, Canterbury mint.

Incomplete copper alloy Post Medieval mount, dating to AD 1500-1800. The mount is rectangular in shape with an openwork design. Length: 65.66mm Width: 25.22mm Weight: 15.06g

depictions.title:
The Battle of Hastings was fought in 1066, at this site around 5 miles from Hastings itself.

The battlefield is now within the grounds of Battle Abbey.  The information board is one of several around the battlefield site, telling the story of the battle.

descriptions.value: Battle Abbey is a partially ruined abbey complex in the small town of Battle in East Sussex, England. The abbey was built on the scene of the Battle of Hastings and dedicated to St. Martin.The name was initially the monastery of St (...)

Senlac Hill (or Senlac Ridge) is the location where Harold Godwinson deployed his army for the Battle of Hastings on 14 October 1066. The name Senlac was popularised by the Victorian historian E.A. Freeman based solely on a description of the battle by the Anglo-Norman chronicler Orderic Vitalis (...)

The Battle of Hastings reenactment is a yearly reenactment of the Battle of Hastings, held at Battle Abbey in Battle, East Sussex, UK, and drawing participants from around the world.BBC News: "Normans fight Saxons... and the rain" (...)

A medieval fragment of a probably pointed oval, lead seal matrix dating to c.1200-1300. Only one half of one pointed end survives. The central motif is divided from the legend with a single incised line, with just one very small fleur visible. The legend appears to read RVS.P.  The reverse is plain with a slightly raised rim. The surface has a grey patina. Length 21.9mm, width 11.9mm, thickness 3.0mm and weight 3.5g. Pointed oval matrtices are frequently found naming priests or women. While fragmentary it maybe possible to tentatively suggest this matrix was a priest's. The VS ending would work for the end of a latinised name, e.g Petrus for Peter. Following the punctuation the next letter begins with P, which may give a variant for priest, e.g. PRESBITERI as shown on KENT-3FB07C.
An incomplete and abraded late medieval silver penny of Edward III (1327-1377), uncertain issue dating to the period 1335-1377. York mint. Diameter 14.4mm, thickness 0.5mm and weight 0.5g.

A medieval silver short cross cut quarter penny (farthing) of Henry III (1216-72) by the moneyer Ilger from the London mint. (Ilger struck coins of classes 5b -7b for both monarchs during the period c.1204-42). The obverse is generally illegible, though the lack of pellets in the hair however would point to a class 7. Dating thuse possibly 1217-1236. The reverse depicting a short cross with a quatrefoil of pellets in the angle and an inscription of +ILG[ER ON LVND/E]

A worn lead-alloy token of the Late Medieval to Early Modern period, dating to AD1400 - AD 1900. Description: The token is roughly circular and undecorated. The back is flat and undecorated. The token is an off white colour and very worn leaving the design indistinct. Measurements: diameter: 14.7mm; weight: 3.68g Discussion: Lead tokens had a wide variety of potential uses such as tallies, gaming pieces, tickets, weights, etc. and are believed to have been locally produced; they are therefore difficult to date precisely. Those carrying initials are generally deemed to be post-Medieval in date (1500-1850), those which seem to mimic Medieval penny designs are deemed to be Medieval, the remainder which carry stylised designs remain difficult to date but the majority are probably post-Medieval in date c. 1500-1850.

An incomplete post medieval cast copper-alloy hooked strap fitting dating to the 16th/17th century. Consisting of a sub-triangular plate with a narrowed rectangular extended curved arm at one end to form the hook, terminating in an old break, (missing it's tip). The other end of the plate has a moulded shallow V in the centre forming a bifurcated terminal with rounded corners. The face is moulded slightly convex with the reverse slightly concave through the centre. There are two rivet fixing holes on the centreline of the plate. The surface displays a fairly even pale green patina. Length 32.3mm, width 12.8mm, thickness 1.3mm and weight 2.5g. A similar fitting can be seen at database record OXON-C4AD6F and gives the following reference;   Margeson (1993) illustrates similar examples, Nos. 257 and 258, and dates these to the late 16th to early 17th centuries and comments these may be related to sword belts.
A medieval silver penny of Edward I (1272-1307) mint of Durham, class 9 dating to c.1299-1301. N.1036.

A very corroded Roman copper-alloy coin, probably an as or dupondius of unclear ruler, dating to the period c.AD 41-260. Obverse and reverse types are illegible. Unclear mint.  Diameter 21.2mm, thickness 2.5mm and weight 5.6g.

A very corroded illegible square 2.7g bi-face coin weight of probable late to post medieval date. Sub-square in plan and flat in profile. Both faces are illegible except for circular scribed outer borders. The surface is rough and has a corroded brownish green patina. Sub-square 14.9mm x 15.0mm, thickness 2.0mm and weight 2.7g.

An incomplete cast copper-alloy casket key of probable late to post medieval date. The key has a sub-circular bow with a round  perforation. The shaft is oval in cross-section and widens, tapering gently towards the bit end where it is hollow to a depth of 10mm. The bit is incomplete, but of a rectangular shape at it's attachment to the shaft. The key is bent between the bow and the shaft, probably from post depositional damage. The surface displays a light green patchy patina. Length 32.0mm, bow diameter 9.8mm, oval shaft 3.4mm x 2.6mm and weight 2.6g.

An incomplete cast lead bi-face token of Powell type 2 / 16 (initials / shields) probably dating to the post medieval period. Round and flat in form, with just over half of the token remaining. The obverse has the initial letters W B in one line with a central stylised sun above, all within an outer pelleted border. The reverse depicts a shield bearing a perched bird right, all within an outer pelleted border. The surface displays a light grey colour. Diameter 13.7mm, thickness 2.2mm and weight 2.1g. Similar tokens from the local area are recorded at; PUBLIC-719FF9  PUBLIC-5D393C  PUBLIC-85BC11  PUBLIC-244B21

A very worn and corroded post medieval Antwerp struck, square bi-face 2.7g coin-weight.. Used to weigh the Spanish Netherlands gold half real coin during the period c.1521-98. Sub-square in plan and flat in profile. One face depicts the hand of Antwerp with no makers initials legible. The reverse depicts a crowned flat topped shield over a cross fleuretty, with the shield bearing a double headed eagle with spread wings, all within an outer circular scribed border. The surface displays a pale green patina with patches of reddish brown corrosion. Sub-square 14.7mm x 13.7mm, thickness 2.0mm and weight 2.7g.
An incomplete and scuffed post-medieval silver penny of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) from the London Tower mint. third issue c.1583 - 1603 AD. Mintmark 2 dating to 1602. North (1991) no. 2017.

An incomplete post medieval, roughly cast copper-alloy double loop buckle frame dating to c.1500-1650. The frame is sub-oval in plan and flat in profile, moulded bevelled around the outside on the face and flat on the reverse. The sides are unusually straight, with curved outside edges and a narrowed strap bar that form two D-shaped loops. There is considerable iron oxide on the strap bar indicating an iron pin that is now missing. The surface is quite rough with a patchy pale green patina. Length 26.2mm, width 22.4mm, thickness 3.0mm and weight 3.9g. Whitehead (2003) Buckles 1250-1800, p.55, no.317.

A Low Countries issued late medieval copper-alloy square 3.2g coin-weight for the Gouden Leeuw (Golden Lion) coin or it's fractions. Probably used during the reign of Philip the Good of Burgundy c.1419-67. Sub-square in plan and flat in profile. One face depicts a rampant lion between three pillars on either side, with three triangular arches above, all within a double scribed circular border. The reverse possibly depicts a barely legible hand of Antwerp. The surface displays a patchy green patina. Sub-square 15.4mm x 15.3mm, thickness 2.5mm and weight 3.2g.
A very worn, crumpled and damaged medieval silver continental imitation of a penny Edward I (1272-1307) or  Edward II (1307-1327). Probably dating to the period 1310-1315. Mayhew type no. 397.

An incomplete late medieval cast copper-alloy single loop buckle frame dating to c.1250-1500. The frame has a rounded outside edge and sides, with a slightly recessed and constricted strap bar forming a D-shaped loop,  The frame face is moulded bevelled on the outside and on the inside of the reverse. The pin is missing and the surface displays an even dark green patina. Length 14.1mm, width 17.5mm, thickness 2.5mm and weight 0.9g. Compare with published records;  NARC-F84394 and BH-05C2E7.  Whitehead (2003) Buckles 1250-1800, page 19, shows similar buckles.

A complete Medieval copper-alloy cruciform strap distributor with attached strap ends dating c. 1200-1400.  The object comprises a openwork cruciform strap distributor with a raised vertical ridge within each internal angle and recessed bars on each outside end for the strap ends. Three strap ends are attached to three of the bars, each with a lenticular upper plate which narrows and loops over and under the bar flaring into a shorter sub-oval plate with a circular perforation. The upper and lower plate are secured with a rivet attached to the upper lenticular plate which passes through the lower perforated plate and is flattend to secure.  Measurements: Cruciform strap distributor: length: 19.25mm; width: 18.26mm; thickness at internal corners: 4.63mm.  Looped attachments: length: 18.2mm; width: 5.3mm; height (both plates): 8.2mm.  Total weight: 7.14g.  Similar examples recorded on the database include: GLO-E30826 and GLO-B4ACE7 which notes that an example from Winchester (Biddle 1990, no. 1402) was found in an early 13th-century context.

An incomplete, cast, copper-alloy annular brooch dating c. AD. 1250-1400. The external edge of the annular frame is engrailed and between each point are eight raised and slightly outward projecting, circular, turret like collets evenly spaced around the plate. All but one contain a white paste and there is a deep circular indentation at the base of each collet on the interior side. There is a circular perforation within the frame between two collets for the attachment of the wire pin which is missing. The reverse of the plate is plain and undecorated. The frame is a dark green with visible tool marks between the collets.  Measurements: diameter: 25.45mm; height from base to top of collets: 4.14mm and weight: 3.44g.  Other similar recorded examples on the database include: SUR-BE1166 and SF-80741B. Similar examples are illustrated in (Griffiths et al. 2007, 143, particularly no: 1723). Evidence from excavated examples (ibid., 144) suggests a mid-13th to 14th century AD date for this style of brooch.
A very worn medieval silver cut-half short cross penny of John (1199-1216), class 4b (c.1200-1204) - Spink 1348C; North (1994) 968/2.

A small lead artillery round, likely of 15th-17th century  Description: The object is roughly spherical though heavily dented, warped and missing chunks due to plough or other depositional damage. Some damage on one side may show evidence of it skipping across the ground after it was fired. It has an off-white colour typical of patinated lead. Measurements: 41.91mm diameter and 430g in weight.
Sandwich Guildhall

A silver medieval penny from the reign of Edward II (1307-1327). Long cross with three pellets in each angle on the reverse. Minted in Durham. Probably class 11 (North vol. 2 (1994) p. 36, no. 1060-1062), which is dated c.1310-1314. Overall it is in good condition, but there is significant wear at the start of the obverse legend and at the end of the mint location on the reverse. The coin is also slightly distorted. Obverse legend: [ED]WAR R ANGL DNS [HYB] Obverse description: Crowned bust facing Reverse legend: CIVI TAS DVN EL[M] Reverse description: Long cross with three pellets in each angle Diameter: 18.8mm Thickness: 0.5mm Weight: 1.30g

A complete silver penny of the medieval period from the reign of Edward I (AD1272-1307). North vol. 2, 31, Class 10cf (dated 1301-1310), possibly no. 1040. The coin is in good condition with some wear on both faces and heavily clipped. Obverse description: Crowned bust facing with bifoliate crown Obverse inscription: EDWAR[ANGL] DNS hYB Reverse description: Long cross dividing the legend with three pellets in each quarter. Reverse inscription: CIVI TAS LON DON Diameter: 16.41mm Thickness: 0.51mm Weight: 0.9g

A complete silver penny of the Medieval period from the reign of Henry III (1216-1272). Voided Long Cross - Class 3bc - c.AD1248-50 - Minted in York by Tomas - North 987/1 Obverse description:Crowned bust facing. Obverse inscription:[hENRICV]S REX III. Reverse description:Voided long cross dividing the legend with three pellets in each quarter. Reverse inscription:[TOM] ASO [NN] ORh The coin is in a fair condition with some wear on both faces; it has been folded in half from 10 to 4 o'clock causing a split; there is another split in the metal at right angles to this from 8 o'clock towards the centre of the coin. Thickness: 0.75 mm Weight: 1.3 g Diameter: 18.5 mm

Medieval cut voided long cross half penny, probably of Henry III, dated to 1247-1272. Coin is in good condition except where localised wear on reverse has obscured one quarter. Obverse: Crowned bust facing with right side only. One pearl of crown is present, so probably only three originally present. Two hair curls, each with pellet. Beard indistinct. No neck or drapery visible. Legend: Upper portion clipped away and lower portion is unclear. Reverse: Voided long cross dividing legend. Three pellets in each quarter. Legend: mostly clipped, possibly ARD, but only lower part of letters is present. Diameter:14.41mm Thickness: 0.5mm Weight: 0.5g

Medieval long cross silver penny, probably Edward I (1272-1307), but could be a subsequent Edward. Flan is folded and dented, which has obscured detail in the central field of the coin. Parts of the legend are worn away and clipped. Obverse: Crowned bust facing, but damaged and not visible. Legend: EDWA[---]NGLDNS[H]yB. Initial cross pattee. Reverse: Long cross dividing legend, 3 pellets in each quarter. Legend: CIVI/TAS/[CAN]/TOR Diameter: 17.69mm Thickness: 0.6mm Weight: 1.3g

A complete silver Eighth thistle merk from the reign of James VI (AD1567-1625). Obverse description: Crowned shield of Scotland Obverse inscription: IACOBVS 6 D G R SCOTORVM with pellet stops. Reverse description: Crowned thistle Reverse inscription: REGEM IOVA PROTEGIT 1602 with pellet stops. The coin is in a good condition with a little wear on both faces and clipping along the edges. Diameter: 17.11mm Thickness: 0.48mm Weight: 0.8g Spink, Coins of Scotland Ireland & the Islands, p74, no. 5500.

A near spherical glass bead appearing black, but made from translucent purple glass. It was made by wrapping molten glass around a mandrel and faint striations can be seen in the glass. Around the perforation the glass is layered in a spiral, which confirms the manufacture method. There is no weathering on the surface except for a few faint scratches. Likely modern in date. Diameter: 13.83mm Height: 11.34mm Perforation diameter: 2.40mm Weight: 3.0g

A complete caste copper-alloy furniture drawer handle dating to c. mid-17th–early 18th centuries. The loop is at the apex of the object and is sub-rectagular. This joins the body of the pendant with a slightly narrowed neck. The main part of the body is bifurcated (or fish-tailed) and has a shield or pine-cone shaped incised lines. Overall, the pendant curves outward. The back is undecorated and there are dished points where the metal would have been thick from the casting process. There are marks on the back that could have been left from a soldered on loop placed on the back, but this could just be corrossion. The patina is primarily brown with patches of green corrossion product. The patina, corrossion, and form of the cast metal suggests a post-medieval date. Length: 46mm Width: 32.86mm Weight: 10.5g Similar examples have been recorded on the PAS database: NLM-C92DCD, SUSS-D549DC, LVPL-10DCF3, IOW-C2FE99, and SUSS-DB9221.

An incomplete and worn medieval short-cross cut halfpenny, of Henry II, AD 1154-1189. Class 5c, Winchester mint (moneyer not present), North 971, c.AD1204-9 Obverse: crowned bust facing with sceptre hE[NRICUS R] EX Reverse: voided short cross [---]/[O]N WINC Measurements: 18.91mm long, 9.11mm wide and 0.6g in weight

A copper-alloy fragment of a possible penannular bangle, possibly medieval in date (c AD 410-1450). The bracelet is D-shaped in plan with curved edges, narrowing at both ends.The terminals end abruptly and are not neatly finished, which leaves some doubt to the identification. The object is patinated a dark green colour with numerous brown patches and is undecorated. It is approximately 60.72mm in diameter, 5.47mm thick and weighs 40.1g. It is 13.43mm at its widest tapering to 8.37mm and 7.27mm at its terminals. Similar objects can be seen on the database at LVPL-DF7B67, LVPL-73A986 and KENT-391C27

An incomplete copper-alloy ramrod housing from the post-medieval period (AD1700-1800). The object consists of a tube made from a sheet of metal folded together and creating a tab with a perforation, which is slightly damaged on this example. On the underside of the tube where it joins the pan, there is a soldered join with a moulded section at the base. This then leads to a flat pan that flares out to a rounded edge and then narrows inwards to come to a flattened point. No decoration or marks can be seen on any surface. The tubular open end would have been nearest the muzzle. Similar but less complete examples of this object can be seen on the PAS database at BERK-FAC4F2 WMID-B4FF7D. The latter record notes that: "Such ramrod pipe skirts can be seen on the Brown Bess rifle or musket of the mid 18th century AD.". Length: 104.09mm Width: 15.33mm Thickness: 14.52mm Weight: 15g

A silver cut half penny of the medieval period from the reign of Henry III (AD1216-1272). Obverse description: Crowned bust facing in a triangle holding sceptre. Only the neck and lower portion of the face remains. Obverse inscription: [hENRI]CVS [REX III]. Reverse description: Voided long cross dividing legend with three pellets in each quarter. Reverse inscription: [---] OND [---] The coin is in a fair condition with some wear on both faces. It was cut from 9 o'clock to 3 o'clock. There is little of the bust to be able to classify the coin further as most of the reverse inscription is illegible or missing. Length: 17.17mm Width: 8.39mm Weight: 0.6g Spink (2003) 124, nos 6235, 6236, 6240, 6241, 6242 Spink (2003) Coins of Scotland, Ireland, and the Islands (Jersey, Guernsey, Man & Lundy). Pre-decimal Issues. Second edition. London: Spink.

A near complete silver penny of the medieval period from the reign of Henry III (AD1216-1272). Obverse description: Crowned bust facing holding sceptre. Obverse inscription: hENRICVS REX III. Reverse description: Voided long cross dividing legend with three pellets in each quarter. Reverse inscription: RAN DVL FON SED The coin is in a good condition with some wear on both faces. It has been cliipped around the edge especially from 9 to 12 o'clock. Minted in Bury St Edmunds by Randulf Thickness: 0.91mm Weight: 1.2g Diameter: 18.02mm North vol 1 p227, no 992/2 class 5b(2)

A complete copper-alloy scale pan of the post-medieval period (AD1600-1700). The object is circular with three circular perforations evenly spaced around the edge. It is slightly concave and has a turned down lip on the edge. There is no decoration on any surface. The patina of the metal is generally a dark grey colour with some lighter patches in places. Diameter: 32.79mm Thickness: 1.58mm Weight: 3.7g Scale pans were suspended from beams and attached to balances, the most wide spread use of the latter likely being for weighing coins (Egan 1998, 322-3). Several examples of scale pans are recorded on the PAS database (LON-6FFFE7 and LON-3745E1) that suggest a date range of 1600 to 1700. However, a similar example is illustrated in Egan (1998, no. 1042), with the suggestion that some may date as early as the late 15th century. Egan, G. (1998) The Medieval Household, Daily Living c. 1150-1450, London: The Stationary Office.

An incomplete post-medieval silver cufflink (c.1725-1850). The object is one part of a single cufflink or cufflink element/disc. It consists of a pressed silver, octagonal disc with down-turned edge. An incised line encloses an octagonal field with an unusual design of six ivy leaves of different sizes that lay at different angles. Behind the leaves is a pattern of incised semi-circular lines in a multiple 'rainbow' pattern.The original silver wire attachment hoop on the back is missing but it would have originally been linked by an elongated oval silver wire loop that was threaded through the attachment hoops. The cufflink measures 9.46mm wide, weighs 0.4g and is 2.20mm thick. Although there are numerous cufflinks of this shape on the database, there are none with a similar pattern; however, it is generally recognised that octagonal shaped cufflinks did not appear until c.1725. Therefore, as this object is probably less than 300 years old, it does not qualify as treasure under the 1996 Treasure Act.

Description: A complete silver annular brooch, with zoomorphic decoration, dating to the medieval period (c.AD1200-1300). The brooch frame is circular in plan, with protruding flattened flanges for the pin loop and rest, and broadly D-shaped in section with a flat undecorated reverse. The tapering pin is again broadly D-shaped in section, with a pronounced transverse ridge (possibly a collar) prior to the point at which it is folded through the piercing in the frame. Decorating the frame either side of the pin loop and rest, are two double headed 'beasts'. The heads of the beasts are presented in relief, with squared snouts, pellet eyes set in slight depressions on either side, and separated ears swept back along the body. Two voided saltire crosses decorate the latter, with regularly spaced pellets infilling the resulting lozenges. Dimensions: Brooch frame diameter: 26.42mm; height: 1.2mm; width: 3.6mm Brooch pin length: 24.56mm; thickness: 1.58mm Weight: 4.3g Discussion: Annular brooches of this form, with the pin lopping through a hole in the frame, are illustrated by Egan and Pritchard (2010, 251: 1316), and are accorded a medieval date. Whilst examples featuring zoomorphic decoration are notably absent from Egan and Pritchard (2010), a number of similar brooches have been recorded on the PAS database of which two, 2013-T886 (DOR-5CC922) and 2016-T634 (YORYM-9A191A), are of an almost identical form, save for some variation with the voided cross and pellet design of the beast's body. Both brooches are dated to the 13th century. The beasts depicted on the frame of the brooch are probably intended to be dragons, with the decoration along the body representing the dragon's scales. Depictions of dragons are described as "near-ubiquitous in medieval manuscripts" and art, often featuring on jewellery and heraldic devices (Biggs 2014). Not all depictions conform to the modern preconception of the 'typical 'dragon: a miniature of 'St George and the dragon' from an early 15th century manuscript depicts a more lizard like creature not dissimilar from those depicted in relief on the brooches described above (Biggs 2014; Anon c.1401). Interestingly, the miniature also shows the dragon's back decorated with a cross-hatch and lozenge design comparable to that of brooch 2019-T506. Conclusion: The age and precious metal content of this object meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996. Author: Benjamin Westwood, Finds Liaison Officer for Durham, Darlington & Teesside Date: 31/05/2019 References: Anon c.1401 Book of Hours (The 'Beaufort/Beauchamp Hours') Royal MS 2 A XVIII, f. 5v Biggs, S., 2014. The Anatomy of a Dragon. Medieval manuscripts blog; The British Library. URL https://blogs.bl.uk/digitisedmanuscripts/2014/04/the-anatomy-of-a-dragon.html (accessed 31/05/19). Egan, G., Pritchard, F., 2010. Dress accessories, c. 1150 - c. 1450. Museum of London, Boydell and Brewer.

A fragment from a copper alloy cruciform brooch, specifically a 'Florid' head-plate knob, dating to the early medieval period (AD525-570). The knob comprises an almost spatulate terminus with lappet-like projections to either side of the main body of the the knob. Above the lappets the knob constricts, widening again at a ridge with an adjacent ragged edge denoting the point at which the knob has broken away from the head-plate. The main element of the knob is decorated with an anthropomorphised Stalin's Style I face, comprising two oval eyes with defined eyebrows and pupils (in an almost 'petal boss' form) above a widening nose, and the spatulate terminus forming a moustache. The 'ears' of the face (the lappet-like protrusions) are in turn decorated with the classic 'Helmed Profile' which in this instance have developed almost to a spiral (see Martin 2015, 155 and 157) . The reverse of the brooch is flat and undecorated. The overall patina of the knob is green, with some brown traces particularly apparent on elements of the decoration. Whilst corrosion is evident, the knob is in fairly good condition overall, making the detail of the decoration visible. Length: 30.14 mm Width: 32.97 mm Thickness: 3.72 mm Weight: 12.3 g The 'Florid' form of the "...laterally expanded, planate head-plate knob..." featuring "..elaborate [Salin's] Style I motifs." is sufficient to classify the brooch as a Martin Group 4 Cruciform Brooch (Martin 2015, 64). The brown traces along the "contour-lines" of the face may be evidence of characteristic 'bichrome' or gold and silver decoration found on these brooches (ibid; Haseloff 1974, 8). Assigning the brooch to a more specific 'Type' based on the knob alone is somewhat difficult; However, the knobs of Type 4.5.1 "Catterick", distinguished by "helmed profiles that erupt from the top of the mask's head...", are distinctly similar to that of the brooch under discussion here (Martin 2015, 77). The distribution for this brooch type is also consistent, with a distinct group in the" far north" around the Tees, with examples found at both Norton Cemetery, and nearby Catterick (ibid, 77 and 291). As such the knob (and thus the brooch) would belong to Martin's Cruciform brooch Phase C, and would date to between c.AD525-570 (ibid, 128) References Haseloff, G., 1974. Salin's Style I. Medieval Archaeology 18, 1-15. https://doi.org/10.1080/00766097.1974.11735362 Martin, T.F., 2015. The cruciform brooch and Anglo-Saxon England, Anglo-Saxon studies. Boydell Press, Woodbridge, Suffolk, England.

An incomplete silver penny probably of John dating to the period c.AD 1209 - 1217. Short cross reverse. Moneyer Walter. Mint of London. Class 6. North Vol 1, p.222, no.974-5. The coin is broken approximately in half.

Description: The hoard comprises 20 silver pennies of the Long Cross type introduced by Edward I in 1279 (c.1282-1310). There are two Scottish coins: one of Alexander III's Second Coinage (c.1280-92), and one of John Baliol (c.1292-96). The coins date from between 1280 and 1310. The coins were recovered from an arable field, spread over an area of approximately 20 metres. It is likely that the hoard was deposited during a single episode in an organic container that has since decomposed. No pottery sherds or other related finds were identified. Summary: 18 coins from the reign of Edward I (r. 1272-1307) 1 coin from the reign of Alexander III (r. 1249-1286) 1 coin from the reign of John Baliol (r. 1292-1296) The coins are good silver, were likely in circulation together, represent a selected body of material (in that the lesser denominations of halfpenny and farthing are not present) and were probably deposited early in the reign of Edward II, probably in the 1330s. A very worn and misstruck medieval silver voided long cross penny of Henry III (1216-1272). Class 3c, dating 1248-50. Moneyer: Ricard. London mint. North (1994: 226 )no. 988. Double struck so that moneyer's name partly repeated and some of legend illegible.  Measurements: diameter: 17.7mm; weight: 1.42g

A complete cast silver phallic amulet or pendant of Roman date (c. 42-410 AD).  Description: The object has a roughly reverse triangular top section (7.02mm tall) with ribbed decoration, presumably pubic hair, narrowing to a tapering shaft (16.2mm long) and terminating in a raised band foreskin 10.07mm from the terminus at the front and 3mm on the reverse, and rounded bulbous glans. There is an integrally cast tubular suspension loop (6.7m diameter, 5.73mm wide) on the reverse of the top section.  Dimensions:  30.94mm long, 12.28mm wide, 9.3mm thick including hanging loop. Weighs 9.7g Discussion: Roman phallic pendants acted as protective amulets against the effects of 'the evil eye', a personification of bad luck (Parker 2021). Most phallic amulets were worn by people and animals, the vast majority being made from copper-alloy (for copper-alloy examples recorded on the database see SUSS-0DF903; PUBLIC-56B4BD; LIN-9DF6E7; SF-49E6A6). They were designed to be gaudy and noticeable in order to work properly as amulets. The archaeological contexts of stratified examples, along with phallic wall carvings, such as at Hadrian's wall, suggest a close association with military sites. This is supported by written evidence with Pliny (Nat.Hist. 28.39) attributing the phallus to the embodiment of Fascinus, the guardian of infants and generals. The association of the phallus with children is also mentioned by Varro (Ling. 7.97) who noted 'a certain indecent object that is hung on the neck of boys to prevent harm coming to them...'. The archaeological evidence also supports this association between children and phallic pendants, with five 'fist-and-phallus' pendants being recovered from a single infant inhumation at Catterick (Parker 2015), and a horned phallus amulet found in an infant burial in Colchester (Crummy 2010) as well as small-fitting finger rings such as BUC-C9CEE4.  Of the 451 phallic objects from Roman Britain recorded as part of Adam parker’s PhD, only a single one was silver (pers.comm.). That one object is a dual-sided pendant from the Caerleon bath-house: “Dual-sided, ithyphallic, silver pendant depicted as lateral bar tapering from centre to either terminal with shared pair of central, globular, testes. A small annular suspension loop is above” (Brewer 1986a:167-168). Although only one other silver phallic pendant is recorded on the database (BM-A0BEB2), gold examples can be seen on the database at  SWYOR-E56143 and ESS-0CDDC1 which have a similarly placed suspension loops. This example is different in form to most example recorded on the database however, with the omission of testicles, and the inclusion of pubic hair. The main phallic object class with public hair is the Flaccid phallic pendants. It is therefore likely that this pendant is depicting a flaccid macrophallus, rather than an erect one, with the possibility that, rather than representing the ability to target and defeat the evil eye, a lack of control and an almost barbaric sexuality is suggested (Adam Parker, Pers. Comms.) The triangular portion of this type can be seen on other flaccid phallic objects including harness pendants such as OXON-551EFE, strap mounts such as DENO-B0E1C1 as well as pendants such as DENO-C0709A, however large testes are a significant feature of these objects. It is not possible to narrowly date this pendant, as not direct parallel with secure dating evidence can be found. The large corpus of phallic imagery across the Roman Empire however, strongly points to a exclusively 'Roman' tradition, and thus, in the case of phallic objects found in Roman Britain, a date of 43-410 AD can be confidently assigned.  Conclusion: It is therefore clear that this object likely dates to before 1721 and, as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996

A complete cast copper alloy (bronze) palstave axe with side loop and decorative rib of Bronze Age date, most probably from the period 1050-950 BC. Description: The axe is broadly rectangular in plan and ovoid in profile. The blade of the palstave has straight sides that flare to form a crescent shaped cutting edge. The rear part of the axe (from the stop ridge to the butt) is sub-rectangular in plan and sub-triangular in section (profile). The two sides flare progressively from the butt to the raised and thickened stop. The flanges are fused to the stop and the septum of the axe is relatively plain and undecorated. The casting seams and associated flashes on either side (long edge) have been trimmed and hammered almost flat. An integrally cast side loop descends on one edge; it is positioned immediately below the stop towards the blade. The loop is D-shaped in cross-section. Below the stop ridge of the axe on the upper blade is a central rib which continues towards the cutting edge of the blade, tapering to flatness at about 25mm from the cutting edge. The rib is present on both faces - although better defined on one. Each face has two further ribs which run from the butt to join the central rib at 20mm towards the blade - again one side is more defined. The palstave has a well-defined polished dark green/brown coloured surface patina which is pitted and broken in places, exposing areas of corrosion, particularly along the external and raised edges. Measurments: length: 170mm; width (across the blade): 61.63mm; width (across the butt): 20.8mm; thickness (across the stop): 25.22mm; thickness (of the septum in the mid point of the butt): 7.14mm. The side flanges raise to a height of 9.2mm above the septum. The axehead weighs 387.6 grams. Discussion: There is a similar but incomplete example on this database at DENO-07C564.

An incomplete, cast, copper-alloy, sub-annular, double-looped buckle dating to the Post Medieval Period, (AD 1650-1720). Description: The buckle frame is oval in plan, the upper surface convex and the lower surface concave and bevelled. The narrow central bar is polygonal in cross-section with remains of iron corrosion, possibly from the pin or plate which are now missing.The frame has a deep brown patina with a yellow sheen. Measurements: Length: 29.68mm; width: 22.65mm; thickness: 3.32mm. Weight: 4.68g. Discussion: Similar buckles have been published (Whitehead 2003: page 48, No's: 278; 283). Other examples on the database include: IOW-94274D; SUR-069B29; IOW-96B753; KENT-8C88DD.

An incomplete, copper-alloy and iron knife of Roman date, c. AD 43-250. Description: The handle is parallel sided and rectangular in cross section, with bevelled edges. It has an openwork pelta-shaped terminal moulding with two prongs projecting into it, the loop is D-Shaped in cross-section. The terminal is preceded by a single raised transverse collar. It terminates in a break, with one projecting element from a probable rectangular box handle. indicating it originally had a body of composite construction, similar to PUBLIC-DBA906. Measurements: Length: 32.2mm, Width: 22.3mm, Thickness: 9.6mm and Weight: 12.5g. Discussion: Similar knife handles have been reported to the PAS, although they remain uncommon, see PUBLIC-DBA906, WILT-C86ED4 (near complete), BUC-D4164C both of which have similar construction although the latter is missing its front plates. Two similar examples are present in the Museum of London collection although one is similar shape 19703 and the other is similar in construction A28342. The examples from London are dated c.AD 40 - 125.

A complete Late Roman, copper alloy, radiate or billon Antoninianus of Tetricus I, Usurper in the West. Obverse: Radiate bust right - straight but not sharp nose, full curly beard. Inscription: Illegible. Reverse: Worn central standing female figure left - probably Spes holding up hem of dress and a flower, walking left or possibly Pax. Inscription: Illegible. Die axis: 12 o'clock. Very worn or fair condition, illegible but rather corroded matt dark green/brown patina with a silvery sheen on the bust. This is likely to date between 270-273AD. Reece Period 13. Ref. Coins of England and the UK, Spink 2017, page 60 No. 565 and Identifying Roman Coins, Richard Reece and Simon James, Seaby 1986, reprint 1994, page 22 & 23 No. 25 and No. 37 or 39. The coin is 18.98mm long, 18.41mm wide, 1.96mm thick, diameter 18.98mm and weighs 2.5g.

A complete flake from a prepared core of Late Neolithic to Early Iron Age dating (3300 BC to 1000 BC). The flake is sub rectangular in shape and an off white colour. Part of a striking platform is present at the base of the flake. Retouch is present along the right hand edge and can be classified as short, sub-parallel, semi-abrupt. It measures 88.3 mm in length, 40.8 mm maximum width, and 13.6 mm maximum thickness. It weighs 42.9 g. Flakes like this from prepared cores could date from between the Late Neolithic through to the Early Iron Age. This flake is probably more consistent with a Late Neolithic date (3300 BC to 2200 BC).
A partially worn Medieval silver penny of Edward I (1272-1307). Minted at London, between 1280-1281. Class 3g, North (1991) no.1022. Measurements: 18.53mm diameter, 1.11mm thick and 1.24g in weight.

A worn Post-Medieval copper-alloy 17th-century token halfpenny issued in the name of Edward Brent, of the Pickle Herring Stairs area of Southwark. dated on the token 1668. Williamson (1889, 1034) Southwark no. 340. Description: Obverse: Legend in five lines Legend: 'EDWARD//BRENT//HIS.HALF//PENNY//1668*'. Reverse: A hoy or sailing-boat Measurements: 20.27mm in diameter, 1.25mm thick and 2.35g in weight. Discussion: During the mid-17th century (c.1648-1672), due to a shortage of official coins, halfpenny and farthing tokens were issued by private businesses to facilitate small change exchange. This token is.attributed to a tradesman by the name of Edward Brent who is known to have been living in Southwark from the early 17th century and suggested by another, possibly earlier token to be based at Pickle Herring Stairs (Williamson 1889, 1034, no. 341). He is also listed in various historical documents of the time including as the Assistant Warden of the Worshipful Company of Shipwrights and is known to have had business interests in Kent (Woodhead 1883, 288)

A worn countermarked sestertius of Agrippina the Elder (c.14 BC-AD 33) under Claudius I (AD 41-54), dating to the period c.AD 50-54 (Reece period 2). [TI CLAVDIVS CAESAR A]VG GERM [P M TR P IMP P P] reverse type depicting a large S C. The reverse is countermarked with NCAPR in an incuse rectangle above the S C, the countermark inverted when viewed with the coin at correct orientation. Mint of Rome. As RIC I (2nd ed.), p. 128, no. 102; BMC I, p. 194, nos. 222-223 (with same countermark). The countermark on this coin is typically dated to the Neronian reforms of AD 64, although perhaps reading N(vmmvs?) C(aesare?) A(vgvsto?) PR(obatvs?) rather than N(ero) C(aesar) A(vgvstvs) P(opvli) R(omani) (cf. D. Mac Dowell 'The economic context of the Roman Imperial countermark NCAPR' Acta Numismatica I, 1971: pp. 83-106; R. Martini 'Collezione Pangerl Contremarche Imperiali Romane (Augustus-Vespasianus)' Nomismata: Historisch-numismatische Forschungen 6, 2003: pp. 116-118, 121). However, an identical countermark on a dupondius of Vespasian in the Pangerl Collection (Martini, 2003: no. 60h) suggests this countermark could potentially be slightly later into the Flavian period, perhaps as late as c.AD 71-72 (Martini, 2003: p. 119, 121; contra Mac Dowell, 1971: p. 89). Measurements: 35.17mm in diameter and 24g in weight

A near complete cast and sheet metal Medieval, copper-alloy rectangular single-loop buckle with plate. c.14th century in date. Description: The buckle frame is rectangular with an expanded outer edge, with three transverse incised grooves at the centre of the outer frame creating a pin rest. The sides have two low raised decorative ridges on the outer edge abutting the inner corners. The sheet metal plate is decorated with three groups of five holes aligned as crosses with two evenly aligned towards the buckle end and one group centrally behind them. There are two rivets holes in the outer corners. The reverse of the plate is undecorated. The plate is folded around the strap bar with recessed sides and hole for the pin. The pin remains although is incomplete. The buckle is a dark grey green while the plate and pin a re a mid-green colour. Measurement: 44.15mm long, 19.55mm wide, 4.76mm thick and 8.28g in weight. Discussion: This is a relatively common type of buckle which is dated by Egan & Pritchard,(1991, 96, fig 434-438) to the late 14th century.

A slightly worn and abraded silver medieval halfpenny of Richard II (1377-1399), North (1991) No. 1331b, Withers (2002,45) type 1d, Minted at London, probably rusted obverse dies. Measurements: 14.01mm diameter, 0.56mm thick and 0.49g in weight.

A complete Medieval silver halfpenny of Edward III (1327-1377). Second (star marked) Coinage, 1335-1343. North (1991) no.1102/1, Withers (2002) Type 5ii, minted at London. Measurements: 16.08mm diameter, 0.53mm thick and 0.62g in weight.

A worn silver short cross cut half-penny probably of Richard I (1189-1199) minted at London by uncertain moneyer, possibly dating to the period 1190-1194, class 3, possibly 3ab, Measurements: 18.55mm long, 9.17mm wide, 0.73mm thick and 0.46g in weight.

A hardly worn Medieval silver short cross cut quarter penny (farthing) of John (1199-1216), Minted by Ilger at London, c.1213-1215. Class 6b1, North (1994) no. 975/1. Measurements: Length: 12.57 mm, Width: 9.52 mm, Thickness: 0.64 mm and Weight: 0.31 g

A sheet white metal coated copper-alloy Medieval strap end dating from the second half of the 14th century. Description: The strap-end is formed from two sheets of copper alloy, held together by two rivets, one at the attachment end and one at lower end just prior to the terminal knop. The sheets sandwich a third piece of copper-alloy which maybe a third sheet or a spacer to assist with its attachment to its strap. The plates are sub rectangular in plan, tapering slightly towards the closed end which is pointed and terminates in a small knop. The attachment is finished leaving it slightly concave. There is no decoration save the white metal coating which remains silvery, otherwise the strap end has a good mid green patination. Measurements: 20.36mm long, 10.42mm wide, 2.78mm thick and 2.33g in weight. Discussion: Fairly common type with a number of examples on the PAS database such as DOR-363A1D, LIN-B85D36, LIN-D032B6, SWYOR-031127 and KENT-575EB9. Examples from london appear to be containted in the second half of the 14th century (Egan and Pritchard 1991, 143)

A highly worn and abraded copper-alloy radiate, probably a contemporary copy (Barberous Radiate), Probably copying a coin of the Gallic Emperor Victorinus (269-271). possibly SALUS AVG reverse prototype, depicting Salus left feeding snake and holding staff in left hand. (Reece Period 14). Measurements: 21.2mm in diameter, 1.15mm thick and 2g in weight

An incomplete cast copper-alloy post-medieval toy miniature cannon, dating to the period c. AD 1600 - 1800. Description: The toy cannon is of typical form. The cascabel has a globular knob and then expands into the first reinforce, there is a small thin reinforce just past this. The touch hole is placed passed the second reinforce on an un-modelled part of the barrel.. The trunnions are centrally positioned and projected evenly to either side. With the touch-hole facing up, the trunnions appear to be slightly off centre sitting low on the barrel. The barrel tapers slightly before flaring at the muzzle. It is decorated with a number of incised single bands evenly placed along the barrel. The muzzle flares outwards. The object would have originally had wheels and a wooden gun carriage, all of which have subsequently been lost or decayed in the ground. The object is a dark grey-green with some patches of light-mid green patina. Measurements: Length: 30.09mm, 10.81mm wide (across trunnions, 5.92mm max width of body of the cannon), 5.86mm thick and Weighs: 2.98g. Discussion: Forsyth and Egan (2005, 80-81) suggest firing toy cannons were very popular by the end of the 16th century, but the majority show features that were developed in the 17th - 18th century.

A worn copper-alloy bronze unit of the Cantiaci tribe. Obverse: Horse stepping right Reverse: Horse standing left. Possibly ABC 264, VA 154-7, Evans G14 Measurements: 15.38mm in diameter and 2.17g in weight. Discussion: This coin appears to be of a type recorded in ABC (Cottam et al, 37) as uncertain animal r./ Horse l. and is recorded only by the drawing in Evans. This coin may confirm that there are horses on both sides of the coin but the coin needs further examination.

A fragment of a copper alloy object of unknown use and date, possibly dating from the Roman to Post Medieval periods (c. AD 43-1700). The object consists of a sub-circular loop, waisted on one side and flaring to a circular base. On the underside of the base are the corroded remains of an iron shank. There are no decorative details apparent. The object has a dark to mid-green patina. Similar objects recorded on the PAS database include: DEV-60ACE4 and SWYOR-0E6CA1. Moradi (2018) suggests such an object may have been a lug or escutcheon to hold a handle. It is possible the item was from the terminus of a Roman key, such as IOW-3036C2. However, the example of the key, and other similar examples recorded on the database, has a square base whilst the object in question has a round base. The overall dimensions are as follows: 24.77mm in length, 15.61mm in width, 12.54mm in thickness and 10.55g in weight. Reference: Moradi, L (2018) DEV-60ACE4: A UNKNOWN UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT Web page available at: https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/897949 [Accessed: 6 Mar 2019 15:27:18]

descriptions.value: Rochester is a town and historic city in the unitary authority of Medway in Kent, England. It is situated at the lowest bridging point of the River Medway about from London. Rochester was for many years a favourite of Charles Dickens, who owned nearby Gads Hill Place, Higham, basing many of his (...)

Chatham is one of the Medway towns located within the Medway unitary authority, in North Kent, in South East England. Chatham Royal Dockyard closed in 1984, but major naval buildings remain as the focus for a flourishing tourist industry (...)

Rochester Castle stands on the east bank of the River Medway in Rochester, Kent, South East England. The 12th-century keep or stone tower, which is the castle's most prominent feature, is one of the best preserved in England or France (...)

Medway is a conurbation and unitary authority in South East England. The Unitary Authority was formed in 1998 when the City of Rochester-upon-Medway amalgamated with Gillingham Borough Council and part of Kent County Council to form Medway Council, a unitary authority independent of Kent County (...)

Rochester Cathedral, formally the Cathedral Church of Christ and the Blessed Virgin Mary, is an English church of Norman architecture in Rochester, Medway. The church is the cathedral of the Diocese of Rochester in the Church of England and the seat (cathedra) of the Bishop of Rochester, the second (...)

Strood is a town in the unitary authority of Medway in South East England. It was, until 1998, part of Kent and is still ceremonially associated via the Lieutenancies Act. It lies on the north west bank of the River Medway at its lowest bridging point, and is part of the Rochester post town (...)

A fragment from a coarseware medieval vessel, probably a pear shaped jug, dating to c. AD 1350-1500. The fragment comprises the handle and part of the inner surface of the vessel. The fabric is orange in colour, with a glaze applied that gives the areas where the glaze survives a more buff coloured appearance. It has a sandy appearance, with some large dark inclusions but also white inclusions which appear to be shell used as temper. In the main this is crushed to a fine consistency, but there is one particularly noticeable shell inclusion present on the lower part of the handle, on the outer surface, which is distinctive. It is slightly reminiscent, although more orange than grey in colour, of fabric 23 from the Exeter excavations (Allan et al 1984:33) although it is likely locally produced, possibly at the pottery kilns known at Plympton and Bere Ferrers. The pear shaped jug form is used throughout the later medieval period. Measurements: 86mm width, 117mm length, weight tbc

A Post-medieval copper alloy Nuremberg Jetton issued by Wolf Lauffer II, dating to AD 1612-1651. Rose/orb type, depicting a rose surrounded by three lis and three crowns alternating on the obverse, the reverse an imperial orb within a three arched tressure. cf Mitchiner no. 1917.

An incomplete Post-Medieval silver penny of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603), dating to AD 1565-1566. Second coinage. London mint. North (1991: 135) no. 2001. The coin has been cut in half and around 55% of the flan is missing.
A Medieval silver halfpenny of John (AD 1199-1216), dating to AD 1204-1205. Voided short cross class 5a2, Canterbury mint. Minted by Coldwine. Mass 2001: 36-37. North (1994: 221) no.969

A Medieval silver penny of Edward III (AD 1327-1377), dating to AD 1344-1351. Third (florin) coinage, type 1, reverse 1. London mint. North (1991: 47) nos. 1113. The flan is incomplete, broken at the inner circle between 11 and 2 o'clock, potential singe marks along the lower edge similarly obscure detail.

Cast lead musket ball with two sets of teeth marks from a small rodent with the two pairs of marks about 7 mm apart from each other. The width of each tooth mark is about 3-4 mm and each pair has a gap of about 2 mm between them, allowing for the movement of the metal. The size of the teeth and the fact that two pairs of teeth were used together to try and eat the musket ball suggest that it was likely a rat using its two pairs of incisors. See similar marks in records: NLM-A03BE4, SWYOR-EE6FE5, SWYOR-EE9C15, SWYOR-EE412E, WMID-67643B, WMID-DBB8F9 and WMID-A0F414.

Copper alloy button or mount with a pattern of raised dots within lozenges and a border of triangles on the upper face. The back of the button has an area where the surface metal has been removed in the centre, where the attachment loop has been pulled off, as well as in two arms off the central roundel, which could be where the mount was attached to a frame, edge or strap. The original surface has mostly corroded away and there are raised areas of corrosion which do not represent the full thickness of the button. Bailey (2004) illustrates a dandy button with a similar foliate pattern with pellets and triangles on page 60, fig.9.163, which is dated from the 18th century.

Cast copper alloy garter buckle frame that is sub-square in shape with a drilled frame for a separate spindle. The frame has angled corners, creating an octagon. Within the frame the spindle holds a double-spiked tongue, and there are patches of iron corrosion product or iron oxide at either end, suggesting that the spindle within is made of iron. Whitehead (1996) illustrates similar garter buckles on page 114, nos.733 & 736, which are dated from c.1720-1799.

Incomplete cast copper alloy trapezoidal knee buckle with a drilled frame for a separate spindle. The spindle, chape and pin are missing. The frame is symmetrical in plan and is moulded at the front and flat and plain at the rear and has concave sides. When viewed from the side, it has a downward curving profile. Iron corrosion product survives around each spindle hole, suggesting that the spindle was made of iron. Above each spindle hole, there are three moulded circles, one at the centre and one on either side with outward-curving wings which extend into a splayed and flatter moulding on either side, so that the composite effect is of a scrolled motif. At the centre of each outside edge of the frame there is a transverse grooved pin rest with a lipped moulding at each side. The original patina survives well as it appears from a few black patches that is was under a layer of of black lacquer which would have been painted on to the surface in order to protect the copper alloy beneath. Whitehead (1996) illustrates a similar buckle on page 99, no.624, which is dated from c.1660-1720.

A Post Medieval silver hammered groat of Henry VIII (AD 1509 - 1547). The coin is third coinage; mintmark lis; it can be dated from AD 1526 to 1544. See Spink (2011) p 228, numbers 2369 to 2374 for similar examples. The coin has been slightly clipped around the circumference.

A Post Medieval copper alloy ornate shoe buckle frame with open work design. The frame is sub- rectangular in plan with rounded corners. The buckle was probably used as a shoe buckle and dates from c. AD 1720 - 1790. See Whitehead (2003; 107, no. 688) for a similar example.

A late Medieval to Post Medieval undecorated lead alloy vessel or container, dating from c. AD 1400 - 1600. The vessel is D-shaped in section; being rounded at the front and flat at the back. The vessel is open at the top, and the sides taper towards the closed end. There are no attachment holes or rivets visible, suggesting that the vessel stood on its own rather then being attached to a wall. Similar examples of this object have often been referred to as bird feeders or holy water holders. See IOW-9AEDE6 for a similar example; and for 'alternative suggestions..including: dice shakers, grain measures, blood letting cups, inkwells etc. For comparison, see published vessels: Read (1995, 127-128; fig. 811), Egan et al (2005, 129; ref. 617)'.

A late Medieval to Post Medieval undecorated lead alloy vessel or container, dating from c. AD 1400 - 1600. The vessel is D-shaped in section; being rounded at the front and flat at the back. The vessel is open at the top, and the sides taper towards the closed end. There are no attachment holes or rivets visible, suggesting that the vessel stood on its own rather then being attached to a wall. Similar examples of this object have often been referred to as bird feeders or holy water holders. See IOW-9AEDE6 for a similar example; and for 'alternative suggestions..including: dice shakers, grain measures, blood letting cups, inkwells etc. For comparison, see published vessels: Read (1995, 127-128; fig. 811), Egan et al (2005, 129; ref. 617)'.
A Post Medieval copper-alloy jetton, rose- orb type of Nuremberg; probably of Hans Krauwinckel II AD 1586- 1635.

A Post Medieval copper-alloy coin weight. The weight is square in plan and both faces are flat. The obverse face bears a circle within which is a sword or dagger with the letters G D N above. The dagger intersects the date '1644'. On the reverse is a border of pellets arranged in a circle encompassing a crowned oval shield within which is a square topped shield with four oval shapes arranged in cruciform around the fifth central oval. To the right of the oval shield is the letter 'R' and to the left is the letter 'L'. The initials GDN represent Guillaume de Neve (Amsterdam), who made the weight. Weight: 3.73g.

A Post Medieval copper-alloy coin. The coin is a West Frisian 'duit'. Obverse: 'WEST FRISIA' in two rows and the date 1660 below. Reverse: Crowned arms of West Friesland surrounded by worn inscription which should read 'DEVS FORTI ET SP NOS' (God is our strength and hope).
A Medieval silver hammered coin, possibly of Alfonso III of Portugal (AD 1248 - 1279).

A Post Medieval copper alloy 4-maravedis from Spain (probably from AD 1497 and on into the early decades of the 16th century). See LON-3F7FD6 on the PAS database for a similar example. Dimensions: Weight: 2.83g; Diameter: 24.5mm.

A Post Medieval copper alloy double tournois of Louis XIII (AD 1610-1643). The obverse depicts the laureate bust of the king in profile facing right. The inscription reads [LOVS.XIII.R.DE.]FRAN.ET.[NAVA.D.] The reverse depicts three fleurs-de-lys in triangular formation. The inscription reads DOVBLE.[TOURNOIS.] Dimensions: diameter: 19.50mm; weight: 1.80g.

A Post Medieval silver hammered sixpence of Elizabeth I (AD 1558- 1603). The coin is dated AD 1561, pheon mintmark. See Spink (2011) p254, numbers 2559 to 2561B for similar examples. Weight: 2.34g; Diameter: 26.5mm; Die Axis: 3 O'clock.

depictions.title: In the centre of this view from the end of the Breakwater is the former National Marine Aquarium, with the ramparts and buildings of the Royal Citadel on the right. Smeaton's Tower and Royal naval War memorial are prominent on the grassy slopes of the Hoe. The blue structure above the waterline in the centre is the Lions Den, a seawater bathing station.

descriptions.value: Plymouth is a city on the south coast of Devon, England, about south-west of Exeter and west-south-west of London, between the mouths of the rivers Plym to the east and Tamar to the west where they join Plymouth Sound to form the boundary with Cornwall (...)

Plymouth Sound, or locally just The Sound, is a bay on the English Channel at Plymouth in England. Its southwest and southeast corners are Penlee Point in Cornwall and Wembury Point in Devon, a distance of about 3 nautical miles (6 km) (...)

Her Majesty's Naval Base, Devonport (HMNB Devonport), is one of three operating bases in the United Kingdom for the Royal Navy (the others being HMNB Clyde and HMNB Portsmouth). HMNB Devonport is located in Devonport, in the west of the city of Plymouth in Devon, England (...)
The following is a timeline of the history of the city of Plymouth, Devon, England.  (...)

The Barbican is the name given to the western and northern sides of the old harbour area of Plymouth, Devon, England. It was one of the few parts of the city to escape most of the destruction of The Blitz during the Second World War (...)

The Royal William Victualling Yard in Stonehouse, a suburb of Plymouth, England, was the major victualling depot of the Royal Navy and an important adjunct of Devonport Dockyard. It was designed by the architect Sir John Rennie and was named after King William IV (...)

The Royal Chapel of St Katherine-upon-the-Hoe is the garrison church within the precincts of the Royal Citadel in Plymouth. The original church on the site was licensed for services by the Bishop of Exeter, Thomas de Brantingham, in 1371 (...)

A Post-Medieval copper-alloy Venetian colonial gazzetta for the Ionian Islands (Corfu, Kefalonia, Zakynthos) dating to the period AD 1710 - 1724. CORFV / CEFAL / ZANTE reverse type depicting three lines inscription, rosettes above and below, within beaded border. A gazzetta was worth 2 soldi.

TREASURE CASE : 2020 T318. Description: A complete silver finger ring of medieval date, c.AD 1100 - 1300. The finger ring comprises a circular hoop with rectangular section which widens to an integral flat sub-ovate bezel. The bezel bear incised decoration featuring a central lozenge with a double square-box frame with inwardly curved sides. The box is flanked by three parallel grooves which narrow into the hoop. The interior of the hoop is undecorated. Dimensions: Diameter: 19.2mm; Bezel Width: 7.9mm; Hoop Width: 1.9mm; Thickness: 1.9mm; Weight: 1.2g. Discussion: This finger ring is similar in form, though perhaps somewhat more crude, than a number of examples recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database. See: 2014 T899 (YORYM-03DF22), 2010 T520 (DENO-A0AFF8), 2012 T639 (NMS-EFD014) and 2017 T614 (LANCUM-E195C6). All have been dated to the 12th or 13th centuries on the basis of a similar example found in the Lark Hill hoard, now in the British Museum, which also contained coins of Tealby type and is thought to have been deposited in the late 12th century.

Two complete lead gaming pieces or weights of uncertain date. The objects are conical with a flat base and tapering sides. Both are undecorated though casting flashes remain. The object is 13.3mm tall, 18.1mm in diameter and weighs 15.6g. The object is 12.4mm tall, 17.5mm in diameter and weighs 13.9g. The term 'weight' is used here in its broadest sense to include uses that do not involve weighing (e.g. holding-down, tensioning, etc.). They were commonly used from the Iron Age through to the post-medieval period and are difficult to date with any certainty without supporting archaeological context.

A complete, silver Medieval halfgroat of Edward III (AD 1327-1377) dating to the pre-treaty period (AD 1351-1361). Obverse - King's bust facing with lis in field and legend: [E]DWARDVS REX [ANG]LI Z FRA. Reverse - long cross with three pellets in each quarter centrally and legend: ADIVIT/OREM... // CIVI/TAS/LON/DON. Diameter: 22.8mm, thickness: 0.8mm, weight: 2.1g

An incomplete copper-alloy rotary key of medieval date, c.AD 1150 - 1450. The stem of the key is semi-circular with one side lost to old worn breaks. Three faint bands of raised ridges decorate the stem. A worn break is present to one end of the stem and an ovate bow is at the other. The bow has two short worn projections; one to either side. A swollen collar is present at the junction between the stem and the bow with a circumferential band of ropework decoration. A sub-rectangular bit projects from the opposite end of the stem and comprises two rectangular panels from which multiple wards and clefts project. The metal has a dark green patina and is worn. The key is 97.7mm long, the stem is 8.6mm in diameter. The bit is 23mm wide, 6.8mm thick. The bow is 29mm in diameter. The key weighs 41.2g. Parallels have been recorded on the PAS database including SWYOR-BAAD16, YORYM-42696A and WMID-EB92F5. Keys of a similar form are also illustrated in Egan (1998) p.115, fig.88, no.313. It falls into London type VI.

A complete probable wooden bead of uncertain date. The bead is circular with a central circular perforation. The wood has been painted/stained a dark blue colour. The bead is 8.9mm in diameter, 6.9mm thick and weighs 0.2g. The perforation is 3.1mm in diameter. Wooden beads are very difficult to date with any certainty. Due to a lack of contextual evidence and any diagnostic features it is not possible to date this object any more closely.
A silver Roman denarius of Vespasian dating to the period AD 77 - 78 (Reece Period 4). IMP XIX reverse type depicting modius with grain ears inside. Mint of Rome. RIC II, p.27, no.110.

A complete knapped lithic implement of Bronze Age date, circa 1600 - 1800 BC. The implement is a scraper formed from a tertiary flake which is D-shaped in plan and section. The straight edge has been formed by a break. The ventral surface is fairly smooth with removal scars. The dorsal surface is irregular displaying multiple removals. Short, sub-parallel, semi-abrupt retouch is present on the right edge. The flint is a dark grey colour. The implement is 41.7mm long, 33.2mm wide, 7.9mm thick and weighs 13.7g. Scrapers are fairly ubiquitous throughout prehistory and are generally less chronologically distinctive than other artefact types. They had many different functions as they were very useful tools and were employed, for example, for skinning animals, removing the fatty deposit from hinds and much more.

A Medieval silver penny of Edward I (AD 1272-1307) dating to the period AD 1300-1301, of class 10ab1 and minted at London. Obverse depicts the bust of the king facing with the legend +EDWRRANGLDNShYB. Reverse has a long cross with three pellets in each quarter and the legend CIVI/TAS/LON/DON. It is worn and clipped. Diameter (max):17.9mm, weight: 0.7g
Twelve (12) copper-alloy radiate or nummus of an uncertain emperor dating to the period AD 260 - 402. Uncertain reverse type. Mint uncertain.
A copper-alloy nummus of an uncertain emperor dating to the period AD 330 - 402. Uncertain reverse type. Mint uncertain.

A copper-alloy nummus probably of the House of Valentinian dating to the period AD 364 - 378 (Reece Period 19). GLORIA ROMANORVM reverse type depicting Emperor advancing right holding standard and dragging captive. Mint unclear.

A copper-alloy nummus probably of the House of Valentinian dating to the period AD 364 - 378 (Reece Period 19). GLORIA ROMANORVM reverse type depicting Emperor advancing right holding standard and dragging captive. Mint unclear.

A copper-alloy nummus probably of the House of Theodosius dating to the period AD 388 - 402 (Reece Period 21). SALVS REI PVBLICAE reverse type depicting Victory walking left with club on shoulder dragging captive. Mint probably Trier.

A copper-alloy commemorative nummus of the House of Constantine dating to the period AD 330 - 335 (Reece Period 17). CONSTANTINOPOLIS type, reverse depicting Victory standing left on prow. Mint uncertain.
A copper-alloy nummus of Valens dating to the period AD 364 - 378 (Reece Period 19). SECVRITAS REIPVBLICAE reverse type depicting Victory advancing left with wreath. Mint of unclear.
A copper-alloy nummus of Valens dating to the period AD 364 - 378 (Reece Period 19). SECVRITAS REIPVBLICAE reverse type depicting Victory advancing left with wreath. Mint possibly of Aquileia.

A clipped silver siliqua of Arcadius dating to the period AD 388 - 408 (Reece Period 21). VIRTVS RO-MANORVM reverse type depicting Roma seated left on cuirass, holding Victory on globe with wreath and palm, and reversed spear. Mint unclear.

An incomplete copper-alloy brooch, probably Headstud or Trumpet type, of Roman date, c.AD 50 - 200. Only the lower bow and foot remains, the upper portion lost to a worn break. The bow is circular in section and tapers to a rounded foot knop with a single semi-circular collar. A partial catchplate extends from the reverse of the bow with broken and worn edges. The metal has a light green patina and is worn. The brooch is 30.6mm long, 43.7mm wide, 8.3mm thick and weighs 2.4g.

An incomplete copper-alloy knife end-cap of Post-Medieval date, c.AD 1500 - 1600. The object is broadly V-shaped with a flat base and a curved arm projecting to either side. A shallow groove is present around the circumference of the bottom end and a deep cut remains along the flat base into which the tang would have been fitted. It is believed this form of knife end-cap represents two symmetrical stylised horse's hooves, with the terminal ends flattened to form horseshoes. The metal has a mid-brown patina and is worn. The end-cap is 13.9mm long, 9.3mm wide, 5.3mm thick and weighs 2.4g. Knife end caps are a common metal detector finds and occur in a variety of form. Similar recorded types include YORYM-1E3004, HAMP-5DF802 and HAMP-289682.

depictions.title:
A view across the site from near the Roman signal station. 
The site has seen multiple use over many centuries of time.  There are the buried remains of a late Bronze Age/Iron Age settlement; a Roman signal station; an Anglo-Scandinavian settlement and chapel; a 12th century enclosure castle; an 18th century gun battery.  The site is in the care of English Heritage and is a Scheduled Ancient Monument. There is a great deal of detail and much history at: https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1011374

descriptions.value: Scarborough (or) is a town on the North Sea coast of North Yorkshire, England. Historically part of the North Riding of Yorkshire, the town lies between 10–230 feet (3–70 m) above sea level, rising steeply northward and westward from the harbour on to limestone cliffs (...)

Scarborough Castle is a former medieval Royal fortress situated on a rocky promontory overlooking the North Sea and Scarborough, North Yorkshire, England. The site of the castle, encompassing the Iron Age settlement, Roman signal station, an Anglo-Scandinavian settlement and chapel, the 12th-century (...)

Scarborough railway station, formerly Scarborough Central, is an English station serving the seaside town of Scarborough, North Yorkshire. It lies east of York and is one of the eastern termini on the North TransPennine route operated by First TransPennine Express (...)
