A complete Post Medieval copper alloy trade weight dating to c.1625 - 1685 with stamped crown over the letter C, a sword and a possible coffee ewer. The front of the weight has a raised rim at the outer edge and an indentation at the centre. The rear of the weight is undecorated. The weight is a little below one quarter of an ounce which could be due to surface corrosion. Date: Post Medieval Dimensions: 23.09 mm x 2.96 mm Weight: 6.21 g The coffee ewer mark was a symbol of the Worshipful Company of Founders and a crowned C would date the weight to the reign of Charles I (1625-1649) or Charles II (1660 - 1685).

A copper alloy Nuremberg jetton of uncertain issuer. Rose / Orb type, showing a rose surrounded by three fleur-de-lis alternating with three crowns on the obverse and the imperial orb within a three arched tressure on the reverse.  Date: Post Medieval - c. 1580 - 1670 Diameter: 20.47 mm Weight: 0.65 g Die axis: 12

A sestertius of Hadrian (AD 117 - 138) dating to c. AD 130 138 (Reece period 6). A standing female figure on the reverse, right arm out to side. Date: Roman Diameter: 30.66 mm Weight: 21.81 g Die axis: 6

One sherd of heavy coarseware pottery. The fabric is patchily fired with areas of orange to buff oxidisation and pale grey reduction. Coarsely tempered with sand, grog and calcareous stone pieces.A large, thick rim from a storage jar. The rim is everted with a bead and groove on the exterior underside. Handmade. Heavily abraded. Date: Roman - c. 100 - 400 Weight: 74 g

One sherd of greyware pottery. The fabric is reduced and pale grey at the core with blue grey margins. It is tempered with moderate fine sand. A rim sherd from a necked jar. The rim has an external lip with a hooked profile. Wheelmade. Abraded. Date: Roman - c. 100 - 400 Weight: 16 g

Two sherds of Black Burnished ware. The fabric is the South West variant (WA fabric 1B) with a pale grey reduced core and black slipped margins. Hard and gritty, tempered with abundant rounded and angular quartz, with occasional shale and limestone pieces. A rim sherd from an everted rim jar and a flat base sherd, also from a jar. Handmade. Abraded. Date: Roman - c. 250 - 400 Weight: 35 g

A sherd of Black Burnished ware. The fabric is the South West variant (WA fabric 1B) with a pale grey reduced core and black slipped margins. Hard and gritty, tempered with abundant rounded and angular quartz, with occasional shale pieces. A rim sherd from a flanged bowl (WA type 25).The flange is dropped from the pointed rim. Handmade. Abraded. Date: Roman - c. 250 - 400 Weight: 31 g

A fragment of Roman T-shaped Brooch, dating to c. AD 50 - 150. The wings, the hinged pin mechanism and top of the bow only remain and are mostly covered by corrosion. The wings are cylindrical in cross section and decorated with vertical ridges at the ends. The wings house the axis bar for the hinged pin. The bent remnant of the pin is still attached in the groove between the wings at the rear. The tapering bow is curved and a slightly and any decoration is no longer visible. Length: 24.90 mm Width: 29.29 mm Thickness: 11.29 mm Weight: 6.94
A Roman Large tessera of white limestone, dating to c. AD 100 - 400. It is sub-square in shape, with the upper surface showing some wear. Length: 25.58 mm Width: 19.05 mm Weight: 21.64 g

A late Iron Age copper-alloy stater of the British Iron Age dating to c. 60 BC to 20 AD. A South Western uninscribed (Durotrigian) type.There is a stylised wreath on the obverse and a stylised horse on the reverse. Diameter: 19.14 mm Weight: 2.92 g Die Axis: 6

An incomplete Roman copper-alloy radiate of Claudius II, dating to c. AD 268 - 270. Reece Period 13. Reverse type shows Jupiter standing right holding a standard in right hand and thunderbolt in left. Mint unknown. Diameter: 18.24 mm Weight: 2.09 g Die Axis: 11
An unidentified Roman copper-alloy radiate or nummus dating to AD 260-402. Diameter: 13.37 mm Weight: 1.18 g Die Axis: unknown
An unidentified Roman copper-alloy radiate or nummus dating to AD 260-402. Diameter: 16.51 mm Weight: 1.44 g Die Axis: unknown

An incomplete Roman copper-alloy nummus of the House of Valentinian, dating to c. AD 364 - 378. Reece Period 19. GLORIA ROMANORVM, reverse type shows the emperor advancing right dragging a captive and holding a standard. Unknown mint. Diameter: 17.81 mm Weight: 1.97 g Die Axis: 12

A Roman copper alloy nummus depicting the House of Constantine dating to AD 330-335 (Reece Period 17). VRBS ROMA obeverse type with wolf and twins on the reverse. Uncertain mint. Diameter: 13.55 mm Weight: 0.74 g Die Axis: Unknown

A Roman copper-alloy nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to c. 337 - 341. Reece Period 17. GLORIA EXERCITVS, reverse type shows two soldiers with one standard. Mint is unknown. Diameter: 14.54 mm Weight: 1.05 g Die Axis: 6

An incomplete Roman copper-alloy raidate of Claudius II, dating to c. AD 268 - 270. Reece Period 13. VICTORIA AVG, reverse type shows Victory standing left holding a wreath in right hand and palm in left. Uncertain mint. Reference: cf Cunetio: no 1943 Diameter: 17.56 mm Weight: 1.72 g Die Axis: 2

descriptions.value: Sherborne is a market town in northwest Dorset, in South West England. It is sited on the River Yeo, on the edge of the Blackmore Vale, east of Yeovil. The A30 road, which connects London to Penzance, runs through the town (...)
Sherborne Castle is a 16th-century Tudor mansion southeast of Sherborne in Dorset, England. The park formed only a small part of the Digby estate.  (...)

Sherborne Rugby Football Club is a rugby union club in Dorset in the south west of England. The club was established in 1980. It has a membership of 100 senior players and a further 300 boys and girls in the junior section.http://www.thisisdorset.co (...)

Castleton is a civil parish in the English county of Dorset, lying within the West Dorset administrative district. The parish virtually encircles the town of Sherborne, and contains within its boundary both Sherborne Castle and Sherborne Old Castle (...)

A Medieval ceramic vessel sherd; part of the strap handle from a jug, dating from AD 1200 - 1500. The handle is fluted on the outer face and just one end survives, where it would have joined the vessel wall. The fabric is soft, pale orange throughout and has frequent, well sorted, small inclusions including rounded grey grit and rounded red pieces (grog?). There is also mica. There are patches of a deep muddy green glaze. The sherd is 60.4mm long, 52.6mm wide and 24mm thick. 62.78g.

Two large pieces of debitage, a primary chunk and a secondary flake of possible Neolithic to Bronze Age date, 4000 BC - 1000 BC. The chunk has a blade removal from the dorsal face which is not patinated, and some removals form the right side which are, suggesting two periods of use. The flake has cortex on the proximal end. There is probable edge damage on the distal end, which also retains some cortex, suggesting it may have been utilised. There are also a few removals at the left side.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic or Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a tertiary flake of grey flint. The distal end, and the distal end of the left side have short, abrupt, sub-parallel retouch. The flake is 33.8mm long, 42.4 wide and 8mm thick. 11.8g.

A flint knife of probable Neolithic period date, 2400 BC - 2200 BC. It is formed on a secondary flake of tan flint with cortex on the right side. The middle of the left side has short, low-angle, scaled retouch to form a cutting edge. The flake is 38.4mm long, 18mm wide and 6.1mm thick. 3.73g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic period date, 2400 BC - 2200 BC. It is formed on a tertiary flake of grey flint. The distal end, the left side, and the proximal right side have been retouched with short, abrupt, scaled removals. It is 25.3mm long, 27.8mm wide and 5.4mm thick. 3.27g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic period date, 2400 BC - 2200 BC. It is formed on a secondary blade of grey flint with cortex on the left dorsal face. The distal end, the distal end of the left side, and a notch on the right side have been retouched with short, abrupt, scaled removals. It is 36.1mm long, 14.5mm wide and 5.8mm thick. 3.1g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic to Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a secondary flake of mottled grey flint with cortex at the proximal end and some at the distal end. The distal end and the right side have invasive, scaled, semi-abrupt retouch. It is 36.8mm long, 42.4mm wide and 12.4mm thick. 23.5g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic to Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a secondary flake of yellow grey flint with cortex at the distal end. Both long edges have short, sub-parallel, abrupt retouch. It is 30.6mm long, 27.4mm wide and 3.4mm thick. 4.8g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic to Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a primary flake of grey flint. The ventral face is mainly battered or naturally fractured. The dorsal face is mainly covered with cortex. Both long edges have invasive, scaled, semi-abrupt retouch, forming a scraping edge on the left. It is 47.8mm long, 29.6mm wide and 12mm thick. 15.5g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic to Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a tertiary flake of mottled light grey. The distal end is retouched with short, semi-abrupt, sub-parallel removals. The flake is 29mm long, 28.9mm wide and 6.4mm thick. 5.47g.

A flint scraper and knife combination tool, or lithic implement of probable Neolithic to Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a large secondary flake with cortex surviving at the proximal end. The flint is mottled grey and light grey and has several inclusions. There are previous removal scars on the dorsal face and left side. The distal end and the right side are retouched with short, semi-abrupt, scaled removals. The proximal right side has invasive, scaled, low-angle retouch from the ventral face forming a cutting edge or knife. The flake is 22.5mm long, 30.8mm wide and 9.9mm thick. 16.2g.

A flint scraper of probable Neolithic to Bronze Age period date, 2400 BC - 1000 BC. It is formed on a large secondary flake with cortex surviving at both ends. The flint is mottled grey and darker grey. There are previous removal scars on the dorsal face. The distal end is retouched with long, abrupt, parallel removals at each end, but less in the middle. The flake is 26.8mm long, 54.9mm wide and 13.4mm thick. 21.45g.

A fragment of a copper alloy finger ring of uncertain date, Roman to Post Medieval (AD 43 - 1800). Only the bezel survives. This is oval with waisted sides, but it is not clear whether this is the result or damage or by design. There are traces of a beaded border round the edge of the flat bezel, but the surface is too corroded to see if there is a central design. The sides of the hoop are at a fairly acute angle to the face of the bezel, but too little of the hoop survives to be able to accurately estimate its shape. 17.7mm length; 12.1mm wide; 5.2mm thick and weighs 2.65g. It has a rough green and brown surface, with small traces of a dark brown patina. With no visible design and an incomplete hoop, this ring is difficult to date. It could well be a Post Medieval signet ring, but a Roman or Medieval date cannot be ruled out.

A copper alloy Medieval mount from an unidentified object, probably dating from about AD 1200 - 1400. The mount has a wide curved terminal at one end, like a broad hook, but too short to secure in an eye, apparently an edge binding clip from a larger object. In plan it has a tapering form, broadly triangular, with the body formed of three lobes and the rectangular clip. There is some damage or wear to one side giving the item an asymmetrical appearance. The lobes are divided by ridged projecting collars forming cusps between the lobes. The wider end forms the clip. It has a double collar between it and the adjacent lobe. The end curves downwards but appears to be complete. It is decorated with cast ridges running longitudinally with the whole fitting. The three lobes get progressively smaller from the clip to the narrow terminal. Each contains a circular rivet hole, two with traces of iron corrosion. There is a double collar between each lobe and the next. The final, terminal lobe is circular. The front of the object is moulded, but the reverse is flat apart from a concave area on the reverse of the clip end, and the nd of the clip projecting downwards slightly. The mount is 23.9mm long, 7.7mm wide; 2.2mm thick and weighs 2.30g. It is a brown colour. While it is not certain what this mount would have been attached to, a Medieval date is suggested based on stylistic similarities with other objects such as harness pendant suspension mounts (compare KENT-42DC4A), spur buckles (SWYOR-3B9AB1 for example, especially the circular terminal and projecting collars) and casket mounts such as WAW-201866. The latter cites Egan 1998 that transverse ridge decoration is commonly found in the Medieval period. Though there is no close parallel among the casket mounts in Egan (1998), there is similarity of style. It has also been pointed out that there is similarity to Post Medieval toggle, clasp or sword belt fittings of circa AD 1600-1700. See Read 2008 , page 209 ,number 757 for comparison and DOR-930285, BUC-EAFA1A, and SUR-900A3 on database.

A cast lead weight dating from the Medieval or Post Medieval periods, about AD 1100-1800. The weight is of sub-conical form, and is centrally, longitudinally, pierced for suspension. The object has a height of 27.88mm, and a maximum diameter of 24.71mm. It weighs 89.85g. This mass corresponds reasonably with three ounces (3 oz.) under the Mercantile (3.08 oz) or Troy (2.88 oz) systems. However, weights were constructed for local purposes, or for uses other than measurement - for example line or net weights, while the shape of this example might indicate usage as a plumbob. Compare SWYOR-077485.

A cast lead probable trade weight dating from the Medieval or Post Medieval periods, about AD 1100-1800. The weight, which is very crudely cast, is of sub-triangular form, perhaps an intended shield shape, with a domed upper surface, on which there may be the remnants of decoration in moulded relief, perhaps in the form of a long, or Latin, cross within a shield. The object has a length of 44.31mm, a width of 27.61mm, and a thickness of 21.63mm. It weighs 134.04g. This mass does not closely correspond to known standardisations. However, weights were constructed for local purposes, or the irregular shape could suggest it is part of a damaged larger weight. While shield-shaped weights have been found throughout the country, they are more commonly found in the north (Leahy and Lewis 2018, p. 276). Similar weights are discussed and illustrated in Biggs and Withers, Lead Weights: The David Rogers Collection, (2000, pp. 34-40). Compare SWYOR-7C3B57.

A copper alloy strap end dating from the Early Medieval period, about AD 750 - 950, of Thomas Class A, Type 1, specifically, sub-type A1aii (Thomas, 2000). The object consists of a split-ended tapering plate with curved sides. There are two rivet holes at the split end. The closed end terminal is rounded and broken, with no extant obviously zoomorphic characteristics – the snout of a beast appears to have been broken off. The reverse of the plate is plain, while the upper surface is decorated in the Trewhiddle style. The major motif is a single stylised dog-like animal, facing left towards the split end, but not with his head turned back towards the closed end terminal. There are chin lappets detatched from the head, filling the space between the head and the raised forepaw. The body of the beast is adorned with triangular punchmarks. The space at the split end between the rivet holes and the panel is filled with a spatulate palmette decorated with a chevron. To the right, towards the terminal is a collar consisting of a single transverse line, and three longitudinal lines, probably the ears of the missing zoomorphic head on the broken terminal. Traces of niello might be discerned, while some areas are stained with a dark red residue, possibly depositional contagion from an iron object. The upper and lower outside edges have a border consisting of square beading. The object has a length of 34.77mm, a maximum width of 13.79mm, and a maximum thickness of 3.34mm. It weighs 5.50g. A very close parallel is figure 3.1, D on page 491 of Thomas (2000) A Survey of Late Anglo-Saxon and Viking-Age Strap-Ends from Britain, Phd Thesis.

A rim sherd from a Medieval ceramic vessel; a jug, dating from AD 1200 - 1500. It has a hard and fine textured fabric which is pale grey in the core, and on the internal face, fading to orange on the surfaces of the handle. It has frequent well sorted quartz and mica inclusions and is mostly covered on the exterior with a yellow green glaze. The rim is upright, plain and unglazed. The start of a strap handle projects from the wall. The object is 70.1mm long, 70mm wide, 40.1mm thick over all and weighs 102.22g

A fragment of a rim sherd from a ceramic vessel, probably a bowl of Medieval date, about AD 1200 - 1500. It has a hard, fine textured fabric with abundant angular quartz inclusions and some mica. The inclusions are well sorted. The fabric is orange throughout. The rim is square on the internal face, but steps out to form a seat for a lid and then bends upwards with a straight, rounded top. The object is 48.3mm long, 23.3mm wide, 12.5mm thick and weighs 10.16g.

A flint retouched flake, of Mesolithic or Neolithic date, dating from 8000 - 2200 BC. It is formed on a tertiary flake of very pale, almost clear flint, with a large white inclusion. There is a notch worked with short, semi-abrupt sub-parallel retouch on the right side. The object is 41.5mm long, 18.9mm wide, 4.7mm thick and weighs 2.84g.

Skipsea Brough is a hamlet in the East Riding of Yorkshire, England. It is situated approximately north of Hornsea on the B1249 road. It forms part of the civil parish of Skipsea. A silver Medieval long cross penny of Edward I (AD 1272 - 1307), probably of class 10cf1 dating from AD 1305 - 1310. Probably mint of Canterbury. North number 1040 on page 32. The coin has a thickness of 0.6mm, with a diameter of 16.9mm. It weighs 1g.

A copper-alloy Roman coin; a radiate of Gallienus (AD 253-268), sole reign, dating from about AD 260-268 (Reece period 13). NEPTVNO CONS AVG reverse type depicting a Hippocamp right. Mint of Rome. See Cunetio 1394 on page 120. It has a diameter of 17.2mm and a thickness of 1.7mm. It has a weight of 2.27g.

An incomplete, copper-alloy hooked tag of Read Class E, type 3. These date from the early-post Medieval, about AD 1500 - 1650. The object has been broken in half, leaving the hook and the remains of a semi-circular, openwork plate with moulded relief, but the rest is missing. The surviving part includes three openwork ovals circling the perimeter of the plate, with four nodules between them on the outer edge. The broken openwork at the sheared edge of the object suggests this pattern continues around the plate. Projecting from the tail of the plate, at the juncture between the plate and the hook, is a two ridged collar, which then tapers off to a complete hook which bends backwards.  A cross-section shows the object is bent at a 45-degree angle at the junction between the plate and hook, potentially unnaturally as is apparent by a slight crack between the plate and the hook. The reverse is flat with no apparent decoration. The tag has a green and brown patina. It is 21.5mm in length, with a width of 17.1mm and a height of 14.9mm. It weighs 1.42g. Similar examples are found in Read, B (2008) Hooked-clasps & eyes, page 101 or at Unique ID: SWYOR-074A6C.
A silver Post-Medieval penny of Charles I dating to the period AD 1625 - 1649. Oval garnished shield reverse. Pellet initial mark. Mint of London. Fourth bust. Group D. North Vol 2, p.162, no.2268.
A silver Roman siliqua of Julian dating to the period AD 360 - 363 (Reece Period 18). VOTIS V MVLTIS X reverse type within a wreath. Mint of Arles. RIC VIII, p.225, no.297.
A silver Post-Medieval halfgroat of Henry VIII dating to the period AD 1544 - 1547. Third coinage. Long cross over royal shield reverse. No initial mark. Mint of York. North Vol 2, p.115, no.1853.

An incomplete copper-alloy buckle of Post-Medieval date, c.AD 1600 - 1720. The object is one half of a double looped sub-oval buckle. The surviving end is rounded and has curved sides with raised ridges to either end of the bar which is narrowed. The buckle has a sub-rectangular section with faceted edges. The other half is lost to worn breaks at the outer side of the bar. The metal has a dark brown patina and is worn. The buckle is 22.18mm long, 26.91mm wide, and weighs 3.44g. Similar examples are illustrated in Whitehead, p.70 and are dated to circa AD 1600 - 1720. Ref: Whitehead, R. (1996). Buckles 1250-1800. Chelmsford: Greenlight Publishing.

A complete lead button of Post-Medieval date, c.AD 1500 - 1700. The head of the button is discoidal with a convex front and flat back. The front face is decorated with a raised cross, each arm terminating in three shorter arms which extend to the rim. Shorter Y-shaped designs are present in each quarter. An integral elongated circular sectioned shank is present at the centre of the reverse, set on a casting line. The metal has a mid-grey/brown patina and is worn. The button is 26.4mm in diameter, 9.55mm thick and weighs 19.11g. Buttons of similar form are illustrated in Read (2010) p.77-78 though with a variety of decorative styles. They are generally found in 16th - 17th century contexts. Ref: Read, B. (2005) Metal Buttons c. 900 BC - AD 1700. Portcullis Publishing, Langport, Somerset.

A complete copper-alloy strap loop belt mount of medieval date, circa AD 1150 - 1450. The mount has an elongated D-shaped loop with a single collared knop on the outer curved edge. One side of the collar is lost to a worn break. An integral attachment rivet is present at the centre of the straight edge and would have been used to hold the mount in place on the strap. The metal has a dark brown patina and is worn. The mount is 24.54mm long, 14mm wide, 2.71mm thick and weighs 1.84g. Similar mounts can be seen in Egan and Pritchard, p.230, fig.145 and on the database as YORYM-01D642, YORYM-5041F0, LEIC-13D791 and YORYM-8A9DC7. Ref: Egan, G. and Pritchard, F. (1991). Dress Accessories, c.1150-c.1450 (Medieval Finds from Excavations in London). London: Stationery Office Books.

A complete copper-alloy buckle of medieval date, c.AD 1350 -1450. Meols Type 4. The buckle is a single looped D-shape with a lipped frame and a narrowed and recessed bar. A circular sectioned pin remains fitted around the bar by an open loop though is bent backward. A rectangular plate is looped around the bar by two narrowed integral strips with central slot for the pin. The plate is undecorated. The metal has a mid-green patina and is worn. The buckle is 24.03mm long, 12.81mm wide, and weighs 1.43g. Similar examples are illustrated in Whitehead p.20 and are dated to circa AD 1350 - 1450. Refs: Griffiths, D., Philpott. R. and Egan, G. (2007) Meols: The Archaeology of the North West Wirral Coast. Oxford: Oxford University School of Archaeology. Whitehead, R. (1996). Buckles 1250-1800. Chelmsford: Greenlight Publishing.

An incomplete copper-alloy headstud brooch of Roman date, c.AD 75 - 200. Mackreth 2011, Headstud 4, Plate 72, no.7229. The head of the brooch comprises tubular rectangular wings within which an axis bar is retained. The remains of a hinged pin project from the centre of the reverse of the wings. An integral rectangular sectioned bow extends centrally from the front of the wings, tapering for a short distance to a worn break. The front of the bow is decorated with a single rectangular recessed cell which retains a red/brown corroded enamel. No obvious headstud element remains though the form of the brooch and decoration are most consistent with this type. The metal has a mid-green patina and is worn. The brooch is 14.11mm long, 17.28mm wide at the wings, and weighs 3.43g. Similar examples are illustrated in Hattatt, p.333, fig.192 and are dated to the 2nd Century AD. Ref: Hattatt, R. (2000) A Visual Catalogue of Richard Hattatt's Ancient Brooches. Oxford: Oxbow Books.

An incomplete copper-alloy spur buckle of medieval date, c.AD 1250 - 1450. The buckle has a single looped oval frame with an integral D-sectioned plate. The plate is sub-rectangular with tapering sides and terminates in a squared expansion. A projecting collar is present at the junction between the frame and plate. A central perforation is present close to the frame with a worn break to the bar portion around which the pin would have looped. The pin no longer remains. A second smaller circular perforation for attachment to a strap is present slightly further into the plate. A third, corroded circular perforation is also present at the squared terminal. The metal has a dark green patina and is worn. The buckle is 35.12mm long, 18.83mm wide, and weighs 3.77g. Similar examples are illustrated in Whitehead (1996), p.34 and are dated to circa AD 1250 - 1450. Ref: Whitehead, R. (1996). Buckles 1250-1800. Chelmsford: Greenlight Publishing.

An incomplete copper-alloy vessel mend rivet of medieval to Post-Medieval date, c.AD 1400 - 1700. The object is formed of a sub-lozenge sheet of metal. The ends of the sheet have been folded into the middle and the very tips bent back outward creating a concertina effect. The tips are broken and worn. It is undecorated. The metal has a delaminated dark brown patina and is worn. The vessel mend is 15.78mm long, 15.64mm wide, 2.79mm thick and weighs 1.76g Egan (2005, p.101) notes that such pot repairs were in use from the Early Medieval period but were at their most prevalent in the late 15th and 16th centuries. This type of rivet was used to repair wood and metal vessels. Ref: Egan, G. (2005) Material Culture in London in an Age Of Transition: Tudor and Stuart period finds c.1450 - c.1700 from excavations at riverside sites in Southwark. London: Museum of London Archaeology Service.

An incomplete copper-alloy buckle of Post-Medieval date, c. AD 1620 - 1680. The buckle is a double loop trapezoid with a D-shaped section. It has expanded pointed ends and lobed protrusions to either end of the strap bar. The pin no longer remains. The metal has a dark brown patina and is worn. The buckle is 41.84mm long, 21.85mm wide, 1.91mm thick and weighs 6.17g. A similar example is illustrated in Whitehead, p.82, no.512 and is dated to circa AD 1620 - 1680. Ref: Whitehead, R. (1996). Buckles 1250-1800. Chelmsford: Greenlight Publishing.

A complete lead capstan or 'bobbin' shot of Post-Medieval date, c.AD 1600 - 1800. The object is circular in section, wider to the terminals, resulting in a roughly hourglass shape. Both ends are flat. The metal has a light brown patina and is worn. The object is 31.54mm long, 20.88mm in dameter and weighs 75.3g. Numerous similar objects have been recorded on the PAS database including WAW-D8D15C, YORYM-F8869D and LVPL-95898A. The latter record states that these elongated forms of shot were designed to provide increased power.

A complete lead button of Post-Medieval date, c.AD 1500 - 1700. The head of the button is discoidal with a convex front and flat back. The front face is decorated with a with central pellet from which faint raised lines radiate. An integral elongated circular sectioned shank is present at the centre of the reverse, set on a casting line. The metal has a light grey/brown patina and is worn. The button is 15.2mm in diameter and weighs 5.98g. Buttons of similar form are illustrated in Read (2010) p.72-73 though with a variety of decorative styles. They are generally found in 16th - 17th century contexts. Ref: Read, B. (2005) Metal Buttons c. 900 BC - AD 1700. Portcullis Publishing, Langport, Somerset.

A complete copper-alloy buckle of Post-Medieval date, c. AD 1500 - 1650. The buckle is a double looped oval with a recessed bar, angled frame and expanded triangular terminals to each outer edge. A recess for the pin is present on each expansion and a D-sectioned pin remains fitted around the bar by an open loop. The metal has a dark green patina and is worn. The buckle is 41.77mm long, 23.9mm wide, 3.17mm thick and weighs 10.01g. A similar example is illustrated in Whitehead, p.55, no.315 and is dated to circa AD 1500 - 1650. Ref: Whitehead, R. (1996). Buckles 1250-1800. Chelmsford: Greenlight Publishing.

A silver Post-Medieval penny of Elizabeth I dating to the period AD 1578 - 1580. Second Issue. Squared shield on long cross fourchee reverse. Plain cross initial mark. Mint of London. North Vol 2, p.135, no.2001.

An incomplete copper-alloy asymmetrical buckle of medieval date, c.AD 1350 – 1450. The buckle is a double looped sub-rectangle with separate strap and pin bars. The pin bar is lost to old worn breaks. A projecting bi-fid moulding is present to the centre of the outermost loop which would have acted as a rest for the pin. The pin no longer remains. The metal has a mid-green patina and is worn. The buckle is 22.19mm long, 35.51mm wide, and weighs 6.68g. Similar examples are illustrated in Whitehead, p.88, and are dated to circa AD 1350 - 1450. Ref: Whitehead, R. (1996). Buckles 1250-1800. Chelmsford: Greenlight Publishing.

An incomplete copper-alloy strap end of medieval date, c.AD 1150 - 1450. The object comprises two thin flat plates which are sub-rectangular, straight at the open attachment end and tapering to a rounded terminal with knoped projection at the other. One plate is worn with damage to all edges. Two rivet holes are present, one to the centre of either end of the fitting. The hole at the attachment end retains its copper-alloy rivet. The plates are undecorated. The metal has a dark green patina and is worn. The strap end is 33.84mm long, 17.46mm wide, 2.11mm thick and weighs 4.18g. Similar examples are illustrated in Egan and Pritchard (2002), p.137, fig.89. Ref: Egan, G. and Pritchard, F. (1991). Dress Accessories, c.1150-c.1450 (Medieval Finds from Excavations in London). London: Stationery Office Books.

Late Bronze Age socketed axe of South Wales (Stogursey) Type and of Ewart Park metalworking, dated to c. 1000 – 750BC The axehead is near-complete, missing the loop (with an overall length of 107.5mm and a weight of 436.0g, including some sediment in the socket). The flat-topped mouth is sub-oval (56.8mm x 50.3mm) with a sub oval socket (36.9mm x 32.4mm and with a maximum depth, containing sediment of 41mm). Three of the four casting runner stubs are evident on the face but have been carefully removed. The mouth moulding has a prominent lip on most of one face but the other face has the usual bevelled-steeped moulding. The sub-circular loop (with a length of 37mm) springs from the moulding on one side and has broken just above the moulding. Both breaks on the loop appear to be recent. The sides have a gentle concavity long their lengths and are bevelled to the centre across their thicknesses. The casting seams are clearly discernible but have been neatly finished. The sides diverge to the gently expanded blade edge (with a width of 58.0mm), which has a very gently curvature. The original blade edge has been lost. Both faces are decorated with three parallel ribs, which descend from the moulding and continue for most of the faces (with a length of 66mm). Additionally the edges of the faces are raised, suggesting further ribs. The faces are otherwise gently convex across their widths and near straight across their length, before converging more sharply at the blade, below the ribs but with no blade facet. Hammer facets are discernible on both blades. The surface has a dark-green patina and traces of probable tenorite survive on the upper part of the faces and along the length of both sides. There are crude incised marks on both blades, lying beneath the patina and seemingly deliberate, the marks generally extend from the ribs, including the sides and end before the blade edge. There are addition incised marks running across the blades crossing the verticals. Some of the marks are doubled in areas, suggesting a secondary attempt on the same alignment and implying a deliberate design was attempted. A number of sharpening striations are also evident running both along and perpendicular to the blade edge.

A complete but damaged lead-alloy papal bulla of Pope Nicholas III dating to the medieval period. Nicholas III was Pope from 25 November 1277 to his death on 22 August 1280. The obverse of the bulla is stamped with the faces of the saints Peter and Paul within a border of raised pellets. Above the heads within the border, the saints' abbreviations would be visible with 'SPA' for St. Paul to the left and 'SPE' for St. Peter to the right (SPA = Sanctus Paulus, SPE = Sanctus Petrus). The reverse is stamped with NICO/LAVS:/.PP :III. There is an omega above the 'PP', which is an abbreviation of pastor pastorum - meaning shepherd of the shepherds.

Roman brooch of Colchester derivative, Polden Hill (Mackreth 2011, Part 3, Group 4, Plate 46-47, AD c. 50-400). The copper alloy brooch has semi-cylindrical wings with incomplete perforated wing caps. Each wing, on the outer face, has a circular perforation, although one is incomplete. The wings are also decorated with a double-stranded vertical groove towards the bow head. The axis bar, spring and pin are missing. At the centre of the upper edge of the wings/bow head there is an incomplete integral hook. The bowhead is hump-like in profile with a moulding either side, and is undecorated. The bow tapers and is oval in section and tapers to a broken edge above the mid-point. The surface of the brooch has a matte mid green patina. It measures 19.87mm in length, 32.96mm in width, and weighs 8.89g. The brooch is a Polden Hill type, Bayley and Butcher (2004:160) comment that the distribution of Polden Hill brooches are concentrated in the West Midlands. Mackreth classifies this type as Group 4 dating to mid 1st to 4th century. Bayley, J. and Butcher, S., 2004 Roman Brooches in Britain: A technological and Typological Study Based on the Richborough Collection London: Society of Antiquaries Mackreth, D. F. 2011 Brooches in Late Iron Age and Roman Britain Volume 1 Oxford: Oxbow Books
~~Silver cut farthing of Henry III Type 2b Date 1248 Obverse: Crowned bust facing forwards (bottom left side remains) S REX Reverse: long cross voided with three pellets in each angle IAC
~~Copper alloy Sestertius or dupondius, unfortunately the emperor is unreadable. Obverse: Outline of a bust facing right [...] Reverse: no detail remains [...]

Charles I silver sixpence. Date 1639-1640 Tower mint Obverse: Crowned bust left; VI behind Obverse inscription: CAROLVS D G BR FR ET HI REX Reverse: Royal coat of arms over cross fourchée Reverse inscription: CHRISTO AUSPICE REGNO Mintmark: Triangle

An early-medieval silver penny of Edmund (939-946), 'two-line' type (HT1; North 688), moneyer: Aethelmund. Ref: North 1994: 138. Obverse small cross pattee within a circle surrounded by the inscription EDMUND REX. The obverse is double struck. Reverse: moneyer's name in two lines divided by a line of three crosses in the centre, trefoil of pellets above and below. AÐELM/VNDMO (the ETH are Ligatured)

~~Copper alloy brooch of Colchester derivative, Polden Hill type. It has rearward facing lugs on either end of the wings that would have held the spring axis bar which is now missing. A rearwards facing hook at the top of the head would have held the external cord of the spring. Small shoulders flank the head which is decorated with three moulded low knops on either side of the bows apex. The rest of the bow is undecorated. The foot is globular with a collar above and below. Although the brooch is heavily corroded the remainder of the bow appears to be undecorated. The lower part of the bow is truncated resulting in the loss of the catch plate.

~~Medieval silver penny of Edward II (1307-1327) Class 11a2 Date c1311-1312 Obverse: crowned bust facing forwards EDWA R ANGL DNS HYB (round backed Es) Reverse: long cross with three pellets in each angle VILL SCI EDMVNDI
~~Silver penny of John Class 6b2 dated to 1213-1215 Obverse: bust facing forwards holding sceptre HENRICVS.R.EX Reverse: short cross voided with four pellets in each angle ILGER.ON.LVND

~~A post-Medieval silver eighth thistle merk of James VI of Scotland, Date 1567-1625 Obverse: crowned shield containing the royal coat of arms IACOBVS.6.D.G.SCO[TORVM]. Reverse: Crowned Thistle. REGEM] IOVA [PROTEGIT Ref: Spink 'Coins of Scotland, Ireland and the Islands' (pp. 74, no. 5500).

~~Silver sixpence of James I (1603-1625) Obverse: crowned bust facing right IACOBUS D G ANG SCO FRA ET HIB REX Reverse: Square shield with the royal coat of arms, above EXURGAT DEUS DISSIPENTUR INIMICI Note: this coin has been bent into a love token

~~A slightly squished copper alloy thimble. The outside of the thimble is decorated with irregularly hand drilled circular indentations that spiral up towards the top of the domed cap, This artefact dates to 1350-1500. Similar examples are illustrated in E. F. Holmes' 'Sewing Thimbles', Finds Research Group 700-1700 Datasheet 9

Robertson 2000, 142 no. 629: ""Very near the spot where the last hoard [i.e. Coleford, 1848/9, no. 768] was found, another discovery was made a year or two afterwards at a place called Tufthorn; several thousands of small brass coins were found in an earthen jar, but of these no record was made at the time, and those now remaining are only the refuse left by collectors, who had picked them over." Then came a list of 251 ant.: Ant. Gallienus 22 Postumus 1 Victorinus 73 Claudius II 25 Quintillus 1 Tetricus I 51 Tetricus II 28 uncertain radiates 50 251 -Mrs. M.E. Bagnall-Oakley, in NC, 1882, 55 In 1896, the Misses E.A. and G. Ormerod presented to the Dept. of Coins and Medals, B.M., 9 ant. "from Coleford find" (BM Register of Coin Accessions, April 1896): Ant. Valerian I 1 Gallienus 2 Valerian II (deified) 1 Postumus 2 Quintillus 1 Tetricus I 1 Carausius 1 9 It is, unfortunately, uncertain from which of the Coleford hoards these coins came. Examined, 1948, 1978 (ASR)"

Robertson 2000, 71-72 no. 338: "17 May 1855 "Jabez Allies, Esq., F.S.A., Local Secretary for Gloucestershire, communicated a short account of the discovery of Roman Coins in the hundred of St. Briavel's, near the Forest of Dean. They were found in opening some coal-workings, on the removal of a large piece of surface-rock, in two vases. The specimens inspected by Mr. Allies extended from Hadrian to the Antonines, but many had been dispersed. Five, in silver, in Mr. Allies' possession, were of Hadrian, Verus, Vespasian, Domitian, and Faustina I." -PSA, (1), III (1853-6), 195 Mrs. M.E. Bagnall-Oakeley, in NC, 1882, 53, said the hoard was found "in an ancient iron mine" and was contained in one earthen jar, and gave the following list of 155 coins, all den.: Den. Mark Antony 1 Nero 1 Galba 1 Vitellius 1 Vespasian 20 Titus 2 Domitian 5 Nerva 6 Trajan 28 Hadrian 23 Sabina 3 Antoninus Pius 20 Faustina I 16 Marcus 17 Faustina II 5 Lucius Verus 5 Commodus 1 155 (pl.)"

Complete copper alloy spur. The arms have a shallow oval cross-section that has fleur-de-lis terminals which has a deep expanded collar at its base and a single copper alloy rivet in each of the three lobs of the lis. The rowel shank is circular in cross-section. Date 1300-1500

Circular copper alloy seal matrix, with a hexagonal handle projecting from the rear, there is a loop at the top of the handle with a double recessed colour below. The face of the seal matrix shows a rabbit in the centre facing right eating a leaf possibly seated on a prone figure. The inscription reads S O[.]O[...]N[.] This artefact dates to the 14th century

depictions.title:
The Kilnasaggart Inscribed Stone, a few hundred metres from the border at the Gap of the North in south Armagh. The following information is from http://www.discovernorthernireland.com/Kilnasaggart-Inscribed-Stone-Newry-P14768 , accessed on 4th Feb 2015:

"'Cill na Saggart' means the 'church of the priest'. Standing at almost 2m tall, Kilnassagart Inscribed Stone is regarded as being one of the oldest inscribed stones in Ireland. It stands on the ancient road which ran from Tara in County Meath and through the Moyry Pass to Dunseverick Head on the North Antrim Coast (Sighe Midhlachra).

It has a total of 13 crosses on its faces and the inscription, ‘This place, bequeathed by Temoc, son of Ceran Bic, under the patronage of Peter, the Apostle.’ Temoc’s death was recorded around 714, which sets the stone in the 8th century. Excavations at the site in 1966 and 1968 revealed an early Christian graveyard with graves oriented radially around the pillar and facing towards the rising sun. It is thought that a church was probably located nearby."

depictions.title: The former monastery at Nendrum occupies an elevated site overlooking Strangford Lough.  It was founded in the 5th century by St Machaoi and was, inevitably, subject to the attentions of the Vikings in later years.  It seems that the site was abandoned during the 15th century.   Largely forgotten, it received attention from an ecclesiastical historian in the middle of the 18th century.   There were excavations and restoration work in the 1920's.  This is the remains of the round tower which would have served as a place of refuge during attack.  See also [[3475559]] (May 2013). [© Albert Bridge]

descriptions.value: Nendrum Monastery was a Christian monastery on Mahee Island in Strangford Lough, County Down, Northern Ireland. A copper-alloy object of unknown date or function. The object comprises a rectangular strip of copper-alloy, slightly curved which tapers to a point at either end. Along one face are two raised horizontal parallel running bands and a protruding curved bar. The reverse has a single central horizontal tapering bar present. The piece is likely a fragment of a larger object. While it is not possible to identify the piece, it may potentially be a part of a fitting, brooch or clasp. The piece is likely medieval to post medieval in date.
Silver shoe or hat buckle with scroll and openwork decoration. There is a maker's mark detailing Henry Nutting of London 1795 - 1810AD. The length is 43mm, the width is 33mm and the weight 8.21g.

Irregular rectangular shaped copper alloy hammered coin. The coin is very corroded with some active corrosion on the reverse. It is a mid-brown colour with patches of light green. The obverse detail survives best. The centre of the coin face is taken up with what appears to be a large 'V' but is intended to be a 'Y'. To the right and lower right of the 'Y' there are what appear to be two small 'V's. These are well spaced apart and oriented vertically compared to the large 'Y'. It is possible that these represent two number '7' s. To the right of the '7's and arranged along the edge of the coin there is a very faint suggestion of a further inscription. This appears to be 'IN' but it is difficult to be sure because of the level of decay. There is also raised detail surviving on the reverse but this is virtually indecipherable. Assessment: This appears to be a copper 'maravedis' coin of Spanish origin. These coins were mass produced for circulation in the New World from the early 16th century. The 'Y' on the obverse suggests this may be an early version of this coin. Both Ferdinand and Isabella (1474-1504), and Charles and Johanna (1516 to 1555) used this device.

An undiagnostic chunk of chert, similar to those found to the east of Dinas promontory fort, at Porth Ruffydd (GAT-DDAA05). It is a possible worked piece, but it is not possible to classify the type of object. It may be of Mesolithic date due to the Trwyn Du findspot and the associated finds recovered at the same time (GAT-DDCB03 and GAT-DDD7D6).

Flint blade/flake, truncated at each end and damaged by the effects of burning. A small flake with a pronounced dorsal ridge (hence alternative identification of blade). It is difficult to confidently classify the type of object due to the damage it has suffered, and it is unclear whether all the flake removals currently visible are the result of human action or burning. The flake has a chipped ventral face. The chip is close to the bulb of percussion and may be a result of burning. There may be fine retouch visible along the edges of the dorsal face, and flake removals can be clearly seen longitudinally on this face. These smaller flakes were removed from the core prior to this flake. The blade/flake is likely to be of Mesolithic date due to the Trwyn Du findspot and its diminutive size.

Primary flake from a probable beach pebble. The flake does not appear to have been retouched to any great extent, but has been removed from a nodule of flint, probably a beach pebble. The bulb of percussion is clearly evident on the ventral face, the dorsal face is largely comprised of cortex. It may be of Mesolithic date due to the context – it was found at Trwyn Du, Aberffraw, and another flint flake/blade was recovered at the same time.

A complete lead figurine, of uncertain dating, but possibly Roman (43-410AD). The figurine is anthropomorphic (human like), consisting of a standing male figure. The head is globular but no facial details remain. Both arms are held down in front of the body. No facial details remain. Both arms are held down in front of the body. Over the stomach and hands is the remains of a flattened phallus. The legs are together and the feet merge into a rounded base. On the reverse, the buttocks are pronounced. The figurine is a mid grey colour, with an even surface patina. There is some damage which may have been caused by movement within the plough soil. Height: 60.2mm; width: 17.9mm; thickness: 18.7mm; weight: 112.13g.

Silver denarius of Hadrian (AD 117-38). Mint of Rome, AD 124-7. Obv. HADRIANVS AVG; Laureate head right, with aegis Rev. COS III’ Concordia seated left, holding patera and resting elbow statuette of Spes. RIC II.3, p. 122, no. 716. Reece Period 6. Diameter: 18.2mm; weight: 2.63g; Die axis: 6

Medieval copper alloy buckle with integral plate, of 15th century date. The buckle is incomplete and fragmentary, now in two fragments and missing part of the outside of the frame (with a length of 35mm and a weight of 4.6g). The frame was of oval or circular form (with a diameter of 23mm) and of oval section (3.3mm wide and 3.8mm thick). Heavy corrosion on the frame has removed any trace of possible decoration. The pin is looped through a slot behind the frame. The ferrous pin is comparatively short (at 17mm) and is of D-shaped section, with straight sides, gradually converging to the tip. The buckle narrows behind the frame (to 9.2mm) before widening to the sub-square integral plate (12.6mm wide, 9mm long and 2.3mm thick). The buckle was attached using a single rivet, positioned near the centre of the plate and appears to have been of iron. No decoration is evident on the plate. The attachment end of the plate is heavily-corroded but does not appear to be broken. The surface has a dark-green patina beneath the grey-brown corrosion. The buckle for is difficult to closely parallel, with integral buckle plates generally being longer and occasionally with a hooked end, such as the examples recorded in London (Egan & Pritchard, 1991, nos. 320-1, p 78)[1]. It remains possible that this buckle was of similar form and has now lost the rear of the plate. [1] Egan G. & Pritchard F. 1991; Medieval Finds from Excavations in London: 3; Dress Accessories; Museum Of London

Medieval copper alloy buckle frame of annular type, of mid-13th to mid-15th century date. The buckle frame is incomplete, missing the pin and is near-circular (with an external diameter of 47.0mm – 48.5mm, an internal diameter of 30.7mm – 31.6mm and a weight of 7.9g), slightly distorted. The frame is of oval section with some wear (with a width of 3.0mm to 3.6mm wide and 3.0mm thick). There is no pin restriction on the frame. The frame is decorated with a recurrent series of transverse groves. The part between the notches is not decorated. The pin is missing. The surface has a dark-brown patina.

Medieval copper alloy buckle of annular type, of mid-13th to mid-15th century date. The buckle frame is near-circular (with an external diameter of 35.1mm – 36.6mm, an internal diameter of 30.2mm – 31.6mm and a weight of 5.5g), slightly distorted. The frame is of sub-rectangular section and is differentially worn (with a width of 1.9mm to 2.8mm wide and 1.8mm thick). There is no pin restriction on the frame and no decoration is evident. The pin has a moulding at the base and an open loop around the frame (9.0mm deep, 10.0mm long). The shaft is of sub-rectangular section (2.6mm by 2.9mm below the moulding) and tapering to a point. There is a groove to accommodate the frame at the tip. The surface is corroded with a brown-green patina.

Copper alloy decorative mount, probably of Roman date The mount is of form and is complete (with a diameter of 42.4mm and a weight of 22.3g). There is a slight rim around the edge, before an internal ridge (of 12mm diameter and 4.5mm deep). The mount has a central raised boss (of 21.0mm diameter and giving a depth of 7.6mm) with a concave or dished centre (11.7mm diameter and 3.0mm deep). Around the edge of the apex is a raised rim border. No applied decoration is discernible on the mount. The underside is unfinished and gently dished. Near but placed off-centre is an integral attachment stud of rectangular section (4.0mm x 3.3mm and 3.8mm high and giving an overall depth of 7.8mm). There is the suggestion of casting seams evident on the reverse. The surface has a dark-green patina with some bright-green corrosion. The mount is somewhat difficult to closely parallel although the style and technology are broadly consistent with Roman metalwork and may have been used for decorating furniture or similar.

Roman copper alloy bell-shaped stud with remnants of the iron shank on the base The copper alloy stud is near-complete with remnants of the iron shank corroded over the base and is comparatively small (with an overall length of 15.9mm and a weight of 13.7g). The circular stud has a marginally larger diameter at the upper rim (at 16.3mm). The interior of the rim is bevelled inwards before the raised central conical boss, which is marginally higher than the rim. The centre of the boss is flat with a central indentation. The exterior of the stud is decorated with a turned, subtle double incised groove around the rim, below which the stud has a stepped moulding before the concave waist (of 9.2mm minimum diameter). The base of the stud is obscured by iron corrosion, deepest at the centre, with the suggestion of a rectangular shank. The surface has a pale-green patina. Copper alloy studs of similar form have been found at Usk (Webster, 1995, p 274)[1] and elsewhere. The Usk studs are dated to the second and third centuries AD and are interpreted as furniture fittings. ‘Bell-shaped studs’ have also been found on lock plates and may have enhanced military objects. A basic classification for bell-shaped studs was established by Allason-Jones (1985), and as such this stus is: Type 1, with iron shank, usually caulked or fixed into the head with lead Allason-Jones, L., 1985. Bell-shaped studs, in: Bishop, M.C. (Ed.), The Production and Distribution of Roman Military Equipment: Proceedings of the Second Roman Military Equipment Research Seminar, BAR International Series. Presented at the Roman Military Equipment Research Seminar, B.A.R, Oxford, England, pp. 95–108. [1] Webster, J.; 1995, Furniture Fittings in W.H. Manning ; Report on the Excavations at Usk 1965-76; The Roman Small Finds

Roman copper alloy mount or brooch of Dragonesque type and of mid 1st to late 2nd century AD date The probable Dragonesque brooch is incomplete and slightly distorted, missing both terminals (with a surviving length of 35.5mm, a surviving width of 17.3mm and a weight of 7.2g). The brooch has the characteristic cast S-shaped form and is of flat section (4.6mm thick). The face is decorated with four curvilinear cells containing alternating red and (currently) green enamel arranged each side of a central transverse border. The surface is heavily corroded and any other decorative details have now been lost. The rear of the brooch is undecorated and slightly concave. The surface is heavily-corroded and pitted with a dark-green patina. It seems likely that the item is an incomplete Dragonesque brooch, but may also have been a decorative enamelled S-shaped mount, or decorative element from a larger object. Dragonesque brooches are a British native type with few recorded examples from Wales or the west of Britain, with many being recovered from frontier areas in Northern Britain.

Roman copper alloy harness fitting: terret of 1st or 2nd century AD date The cast terret is of strap-mounted type and is complete (with an overall length of 53.2mm, a maximum width of 52.8mm, maximum internal dimensions of 37.4mm x 16mm and a weight of 53.0g). The basal loop is integral and sub-rectangular (21.5mm wide and 8.5mm deep with internal dimensions of 13.4mm x 4.2mm) and with a sub-rectangular to oval sectioned frame (5.5mm wide and 4mm thick). Above the loop there is an oval moulding (7.5mm long and 12.6mm wide) with a convex upper edge (7.4mm deep). Above the moulding, the hoop is flat and rectangular-sectioned but somewhat irregular in width and thickness (with a thickness of 2.7mm – 5.9mm). The hoop is widest at its base (at 10mm) and gradually narrows towards its apex (to 5.5mm). On the interior of the hoop are decorative opposing ‘C’ scrolls with a bifurcating tope edge. No applied decoration is evident on the terret. Areas of wear are discernible on the inside of the hoop, particularly to one side of the apex. The surface has a dark-green patina with some finishing striations evident beneath the patina. The terret is comparatively elaborate compared to many recovered examples of strap-mounted terrets, which tend to have few decorative features and is difficult to closely parallel. Note: The record was written before Lewis’ (2015) typology was published. Using Lewis’ typology this terret may be assigned to the “Dropped Bar” type, which belongs to the imported types group, firmly dating terrets of this type to the 1st and 2nd centuries post Claudian invasion.

Incomplete silver medieval penny of Edward I (1272-1307). Class 1c North 1012 (AD 1279), mint of London. Obverse: Crowned bust. Legend: EDW REX ANGL DNS [HYB] Reverse: Long cross with three pellets in each quadrant. Legend: CIVI/TAS/[LO]N/DON

Silver 50 Reis of Jose I of Portugal (1750-1777). The obverse has a crown above XXXX and the legend JOSEPHUS I.D.G.P.ET.AL.REX. The reverse has a cross with a 4-peteled flower in each quarter and the legend IN HOC SIGNO VINCES. The coin has been pierced. Diameter: 16.3mm; weight: 1.25g

Worn copper alloy sestertius, possibly of Hadrian (AD 117-38). Mint of Rome. Obv. [ ... ]; Draped and cuirassed bust right. Rev. [ ... ]; Figure standing / advancing left. Reece Period 6. This is a very tentative identification and it could also be of Trajan or Antoninus Pius. Diameter: 29.8mm; weight: 15g

Complete silver halfgroat of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) minted in London. Obverse has the crowned bust of the queen facing left with 2 pellets behind and the legend [E D G] ROSA SINE SPINA. The reverse has a squared shield on long cross fourchée, dividing the legend, CIVI TAS LON[D]ON. The initial mark appears to be a marlet. Diameter: 15.9mm; weight: 0.76g

Incomplete copper alloy trapezoidal shoe or knee buckle dating c.1660-1720AD. The buckle has a separate iron spindle held in place by two drilled spindle holes. The spindle is still in situ but the pin is missing. The buckle has moulded decoration on both sides and around the spindle holes. The outer edge of each loop is bevelled. The pin rests have crudely executed parallel cut marks. The reverse of the buckle is flat and undecorated. It is possible that the buckle may have been tinned originally. Length: 34.7mm; width: 23.8mm; thickness: 4.4mm; weight: 7.4g

Possible post medieval copper alloy strap fitting, c.1500-1700AD. The fitting is axe-shaped in plan with the remnants of three iron-rich rivets at one end. The sides of the curved edge are chamfered. Length: 34.8mm; width curved end: 30.5mm; width of riveted end: 19.4mm; thickness: 7.2mm tapering to: 2.9mm; thickness (including rivets): 6.9mm; weight: 21.9g

A fragmentary and abraded undecorated flat axe of Early Bronze Age date (c. 2200-1900BC). The axe is probably a Migdale type flat axe These are dated to the Early Bronze Age (EBA phase II/III), of metalworking stage IV-VI, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2-3 c.2250-1900calBC. The flat axe is broadly sub triangular in plan with a narrow butt with side expanding to a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile the axe is broadly lentoid, with tapering ends. In cross section the axe is rectangular. The axe is a mid-green colour with a lot of pitting on the surface. Length: 66.0mm; width at butt end: 22.4mm; width at blade end: 46.0mm; maximum thickness: 6.5mm; weight: 83.4g

Copper alloy fragment of a probable spearhead. Dating is difficult due to the fragmentary nature of the object but is likely to be late Middle Bronze age or Late Bronze Age (c. 1500-700BC). The object has a socket that is circular in section tapering towards the point, which is now missing. The surviving blade is diamond-shaped in section. The surface of the object is heavily pitted and none of the original surface survives. It has a dark brown patina. Length: 49.4mm; width: 13.5mm; thickness: 9.39mm; weight; 11g

An incomplete spindle whorl, made from a very worn and fragmentary medieval lead papal bulla of Pope Clement V (1305 to 1314). The obverse bears the legend CLE / [MEN]S / [:PP] V within a beaded border. The reverse depicts the faces of St Peter and St Paul below the inscription SPASP[E] (SPA = Sanctus Paulus, SPE = Sanctus Petrus), all of which are surrounded by the remains of a beaded border. St. Paul is seen on the left looking right, with a long pointed beard and short grooved hair, St. Peter is now missing. A squashed hole is visible on the perimeter at 12 o'clock with a partial hole visible at 6 o'clock; these would have been for the attachment cord. The object has clearly been re-used since it has a large circular hole (diameter 12.9mm) cut in the centre, suggesting it may have been re-used either as a spindle whorl or as a weight. Diameter: 36.6mm; thickness: 6.5mm; internal diameter of central hole: 12.9mm; weight: 23.3g

Silver penny of Edward I/II class 10cf3b minted at Canterbury and dating to 1307-09. Obverse has the bust of the king facing with the legend +EDWARANGLDNShYB. Reverse has long cross, with 3 pellets in each quarter, dividing the CIVI/TAS/CAN/TOR. The coin appears to have been clipped and is slightly worn, particularly on the obverse. Diameter: 17.2mm; weight: 1.3g

A complete, cast copper-alloy annular ring of circular section, probably a harness fitting of medieval or post-medieval date, c. A.D. 1100-1800. The ring has a relatively thin frame and there are incised lines at 2 o'clock, 4 o'clock, 8 o'clock, and 10 o'clock on the faces as a form of decoration. There is no other evidence of wear. There is a little damage to the ring; however, this occurred post-discovery.  It measures 26.45mm in diameter with an internal diameter of 19.69mm, 4.08mm in thickness, and weighs 5.24g. These rings are common detector finds, but their function and dating are not well understood (Geake, Finds Recording Guide).

A cast copper alloy object of unknown function, likely of post medieval date. The object is 45mm diameter disc of copper alloy 5mm thick. The obverse of the disc is decorated in relief moulding, with a circular central cell surrounded by four concentric circular ridges. The central cell is decorated in relief with an pseudoheraldic animal, possibly a dog or lion. The attitude of the pseudoheraldic is passant to sinister (moving to the viewer's right). The reverse is undecorated and covered in a dark patina with patches of corrosion. The object is reminiscent of livery and hunting (a.k.a sporting) buttons, but cannot be identified as the heraldic symbol of a family or organisation. The object also is far larger and thicker than these types of buttons and bears no signs of soldering that might have attached a button shank.

A dragonesque brooch of probable Roman date. The brooch is ‘S’ shaped in plan, presented as a two headed dragon. The heads both have protruding ears, curving snouts and decorated eyes. From the heads the brooch curves and expands into a wider body. The obverse is decorated with raised panel lines and enamel. The reverse of the find is undecorated but there is evidence of two attachment lugs located roughly centrally on the piece. The edges of the brooch are rough. This may be due to poor casting or potentially damage which has occurred to the object. While it cannot be said for certain, it is probable that this brooch is of Roman date and not a modern replica. A dragonesque brooch has previously been found at Segontium Roman Fort, Caernarfon, which indicates that brooches of this type from this area are known of. There are however a number of modern dragonesque brooches replicas.

A lead weight of unknown date. The weight is elongated and trapezoid in form with a suspension loop and square base. Lead weights are difficult to date and the weight could date from the Roman to Post Medieval period. Similar objects have been recorded on the PAS database see; KENT-978DC1 and NLM-22BA0A

A Scottish medieval silver cut halfpenny of William I of Scotland (1165-1214)/Alexander II of Scotland (1214-49), Short Cross and Stars type (Phase B; Spink 5029), uncertain bust type, dating to c.1205-c.1230, moneyer: Hue and Walter, mint: Edinburgh or Perth. Ref Spink 2015, pg 14 The coin has been cut in half and has been badly worn. On the obverse there are slight traces of the portrait and outer legend. The legend is no longer legible. On the reverse is a short cross with a star with five points in each of the remaining quadrants. The legend has been badly worn and is no longer legible.

A lead bag seal from a flour bag (1800-1900). On one side the print reads ‘MOULINS DE BR……… S’, which translates to ‘Mill of’, the name of the town which this seal was from is no longer visible. On the other side the print reads ‘PREMIERS SUPER’. There is a flower in the center surrounded by a beaded border. Similar finds have been recorded on the PAS database see; DUR-144FD6 and DUR-145D79.

An incomplete, Post Medieval, silver shilling of Charles I (AD 1625-1649). Some of the bust detail has been lost due to wear but possibly Group F or G, (North 2231-2234) dating to AD 1645-1649. The initial mark is illegible due to clipping. London mint. North (1991: 160). The coin has been clipped in several places removing some of the obverse and reverse legends. Overall dimensions: 30.6 mm in diameter, 1.1 mm in thickness and 5.6 g in weight.

Two possible copper coins. 1. A roughly circular copper possible coin. There is partial decoration on one face in the form of two overlapping Roman numerals, possibly: 'IIX' and 'IIII'. Thickness: 1mm Diameter: 27mm Weight: 6g 2. A copper-alloy coin or token. An off centre cross shaped grove is visible on one face. Diameter: 27mm Thickness: 2mm Weight: 7.9g
A collection of three pieces of shot. Likely post medieval in date. Suggested date: 17th or 18th century. (From left to right, row by row) 1. D.52mm W.577g 2. D.34mm W.166.6g 3. D.27mm W.112.7g

A complete two part type lead bag seal. The seal is formed of two rounded lead discs connected by a single strip of lead. One disc has a protruding rivet while the second has a central circular perforation. The seal has been folded in half allowing the protruding rivet to pass through the perforation. One lead disc bears traces of decoration in the form of a possible ring of pellets and two illegible letters.

A coin of Roman date. Obverse: Right facing bearded bust with laureate. The inscription is partially missing. The visible letters read: M COMM ANT. Reverse: Liberalitas, draped, standing left, holding abacus in right hand and cornucopiae in left hand. The inscription is partially missing. The only legible letters read: AVG. The coin may depict the head of Commodus which would date the coin between 175AD and 192AD.

A collection of lead musket balls and shot of various sizes, likely post medieval, 17th century in date. (See Image: from left to right, row by row) 1. D.17mm W.30.8g 2. D.18mm W.31.8g 3. D.19mm W.32.8g 4. D.20mm W.26.7g 5. D.17mm W.32.9g 6. D.17mm W.30.5g 7. D.15mm W.18.5g 8. D.17.5mm W.32.3g 9. D.20mm W.45.1g 10. D.17mm W.30.5g 11. D.14mm W.24.9g 12. D.16mm W.24.4g 13. D.16mm W.33.5g 14. D.14mm W.19.9g 15. D.18mm W.30.1g 16. D.14mm W.17.3g 17. D.12mm W.11.1g 18. D.11mm W.5.5g 19. D.10mm W.6.4g 20. D.9mm W.5.3g 21. D.10mm W.5.7g 22. D.13mm W.11.1g 23. D.10mm W.6.8g 24. D.14.5mm W.13.9g 25. D.11mm W.6.6g 26. D.11mm W.9.4g 27. D.16mm W.25.7g 28. D.17mm W.29.7g 29. D.15mm W.20.9g 30. D.10 W.18.4g 31. D.12 W.9.8g

A post medieval rowel spur. The piece consists of two truncated arms, a neck and a truncated rowel box. The rowel box is partially intact, although one side terminal and the rowel itself are missing. From the rowel box protrudes a cylindrical globule neck. The neck attaches to the base of the legs on a flattened diamond shaped platform from which both legs diverge. Both legs are truncated. The spur is likely post medieval, 17th century in date.

A possible halfcrown dating from the reign of Charles I. The coin is lozenge shaped. The obverse of the coin bears a crown and the inscription 'C / R / XXX'. The reverse of the coin bears the inscription 'OBS / NEWARK / 1646' The PAS database has a number of genuine siege/ emergency coins recorded (NCL-B4F01A); however it also has a number of modern forgeries / reconstructions recorded too (WMID-FA6147).

Description of find Ninety-seven Roman coins, dating to the third century A.D.: seven denarii and ninety 'radiates' (double-denarii). A summary list is appended. There are no associated objects. Metal content The coins, in principle silver issues, span a period of debasement during which the silver content dropped from around fifty per cent Ag to issues which to all intents and purposes are of copper alloys (typical silver contents are indicated on the list of coins). Discussion The coins were found within a limited area and therefore it is more likely than not that they were originally associated in the ground. The latest issues are irregular issues from the time of Carausius (usurper in Britain, 286/7-93) adding the hoard to the many recorded from Wales that were buried during this reign. Late third-century hoards typically include only the highly-debased issues from around 260 onwards. This new find is therefore unusual in having a significant content of the earlier coins and thereby a value as bullion; the continued availability of 'silver' coins in the late third century may relate to the relatively remote location in Roman Britain.

A probable incomplete lead alloy artefact of uncertain function, but probably of Post Medieval dating (AD 1700 to AD 1900). It is of a pointed oval shape. Although it looks like it is a two part artefact with one side fitting inside the other, it has been cast in one piece. Foliate decoration around the outside. Circular knops are on either side and the top crosses over and then splits into two separate prongs, with the ends incomplete. It measures 89.1 mm in length, 65.2 mm wide and 7.4 mm thick. It weighs 83.2 g. It is a light to dark grey colour, with an uneven surface patina.

A complete annular copper alloy artefact, of probable Post medieval dating (AD 1500 to AD 1700). The artefact is circular in shape and flat. The back is undecorated. The front has foliate style decoration. No signs of a pin rest or slot are present. It has a diameter of 34.8 mm and an internal diameter of 21.7 mm. The frame is 6.9 mm wide and 1.1 mm thick. It weighs 3.5 g. The artefact is a dark green colour, with an even surface patina. No direct identification of this artefact was possible at the time of recording. It is possible that it is an annular brooch frame but as there are no signs of pin attachment, that identification is uncertain. It is possible that it might be a small vessel rim, but again this identification is not certain.

An incomplete Post Medieval lead-alloy bag seal. The seal represents once complete disc of a probable two part disc seal. A fragment of the second disc remains attached to the rear face of the complete disc. The seal is disc shaped, and circular in plan. The front face, now mostly plain, bears traces of probable lettering or decoration. The reverse of the complete disc appears plain. Part of the second disc fragment remains attached to the reverse of the complete disc. This fragment is sub-oval / tear drop in shape. It bears the possible lettering 'I P', however because this second disc is heavily truncated, it is not possible to discern the full extent of the lettering / or decoration. The object has a light cream patina. Unfortunately design impressions on this type of bag seal are usually weak are not well preserved (Bailey 2000, 16). This example is likely Post Medieval in date.

The truncated tip of a broken flint blade. The piece appears to be a secondary flake with evidence of retouch. The flint is predoimently dark and light grey in colour. The flake is sub-rectangular in form. The truncated base of the flake is flat. The sides of the flake taper to a rounded point. The ventral face has a number of ripples orientated towards the distal end. The dorsal face has a number of negative scars, broadly orientated in the same direction, which may indicate a number of flakes were removed from the same platform (Butler 2005, 33). It is not possible to conclusively identity if the flint is anthropogenic in origin because it is incomplete. If the flake is man made it most likely dates from the Mesolithic to the Neolithic period.

A silver threepence dating to the reign of Elizabeth I (1558-1603). Obverse: Crowned left facing bust with rose. Indiscernible mint mark due to ware. The inscription reads: ELIZABETH/DG/ANG/FR/ET/HI/REGINA (Elizabeth by the Grace of God Queen of England, France and Ireland). Reverse: A long cross fourchee over a shield displaying a royal coat of arms. The coin is dated 15??. The full inscription reads: POSVI/DEV AD/IVTORE/M MEV (I have made God my Helper). Discussion: The rose to the left of the bust was used to distinguish the sixpence, threepence, three halfpence and threefarthings from the shilling, groat, half-groat and penny (Mitchell & Reeds 1997, 171). Because the coin is worn particularly on the date and mark it is not possible to discern the exact date or issue of the coin.

descriptions.value: Beaumaris is a former royal borough, a community, and the former county town of Anglesey, Wales. It was located in the commote of Dindaethwy and historic rural deanery of Tindaethwy, and is at the eastern entrance to the Menai Strait, the tidal waterway separating Anglesey from the coast of North (...)

Beaumaris Castle, located in the town of the same name on the Isle of Anglesey in Wales, was built as part of Edward I's campaign to conquer the north of Wales after 1282. Plans were probably first made to construct the castle in 1284, but this was delayed due to lack of funds and work only began in (...)

Llangoed is a small village, community and electoral ward just north of Beaumaris, on the Isle of Anglesey or Ynys Môn, at . The Royal Mail postcode begins LL58. Llangoed ward has a population of 1,275 (2001), falling at the 2011 census to 1,229 (...)

Robertson 2000, 9 no. 39: ""In February 1961 Mr. Edward Jones was cultivating a field on Ty Aur Farm, Llanelen, when he noticed the rim of a coin protruding from the ground. The coin was sent to the National Museum of Wales, and proved to be an almost unworn aureus of Claudius I, struck at Rome AD 51-52. The names of the farm and of the barn - Ysgubor Aur - adjoining the field in which the discovery was made, incorporate the Welsh word for metallic gold and suggest that a hoard existed at some remote time; although a careful visual search, coupled with the use of a mine-detector kindly supplied by the Territorial Army H.Q., Cardiff (proved to be capable of detecting gold if shallowly buried) failed to reveal other coins. The site, however, is a sloping field at the foot of Coed y Prior, a steep hillside flanking the eastern edge of the uplands which terminate northward in the Blorenge; and the lower part of the field, where the coin was found, is deep in hill-wash. A hoard buried in Coed y Prior, if disturbed by natural agency, would probably have become dispersed, in time, over a very wide area. The condition of the aureus suggests loss or burial within a year or two of mintage. " G.C. Boon, in BBCS XIX (1961-2), 345f. G.C. Boon, in Monmouths. Antiquary, I (i) (1961), 1-5, type, photo of aureus, gave a full discussion of the coin. Including Claudius"

Medieval lead pilgrim's ampulla of 14th to 16th century date The ampulla is incomplete, missing the mouth and loops (with a surviving length of 45.9mm and a weight of 32.2g). The neck is open (with a depth of 7.7mm) and the tear is damaged to one side (with an undamaged width of 18.1mm). There is some damage on the side of the neck, above the body suggesting the position of the missing loop. The obverse face was convex and has a linear groove, partially closing the neck. The reverse face is flat and both faces are without decoration. The body of the ampulla is curved (with a width of 25.9mm). The obverse face has bold radiating ribs producing a corrugated surface, of Spencer's (1990, p 59)[1] Type I and indicating the scallop shell, the emblem of Saint James and representing pilgrimage. There is a diagonal moulding running across the face, possibly a casting flaw. The reverse face is flat and is without any discernible design. The ampulla has a grey-white corroded surface. [1] Spencer, B. 1990; Salisbury & South Wiltshire Medieval Catalogue, Part 2, Pilgrim Souvenirs & Secular Badges; Salisbury & South Wiltshire Museum

descriptions.value: Blaenavon is a town and World Heritage Site in south eastern Wales, lying at the source of the Afon Lwyd north of Pontypool, within the boundaries of the historic county of Monmouthshire and the preserved county of Gwent. The town lies high on a hillside and has a population of 6,055 (...)

Blaenavon Ironworks is a former industrial site which is now a museum in Blaenavon in Wales. The ironworks was of crucial importance in the development of the ability to use cheap, low quality, high sulphur iron ores worldwide (...)

The Clydach Gorge (also known as Cwm Clydach) is a steep-sided valley in south-east Wales down which the River Clydach flows to the River Usk. It runs for 5.6 km from the vicinity of Brynmawr in Blaenau Gwent eastwards and northeastwards to Gilwern in Monmouthshire (...)

BlorengeOrdnance Survey 1:25,000 scale Explorer map sheet OL13 Brecon Beacons National Park: eastern area or sometimes The Blorenge is a prominent hill which overlooks the valley of the River Usk in Monmouthshire, southeast Wales (...)
Clydach is a village in Monmouthshire, Wales. Its nearest neighbours are the village of Gilwern and town of Abergavenny.  (...)
